weekly_outlook: Gore joins the Bills as a complement to rookie Devin Singletary after a bizarre 2018 season in Miami, during which he averaged a healthy 4.6 YPC (2.3 YAC), but failed to rush for a single touchdown. Gore finished 46th at the position in fantasy points, which is the first time he has finished a season worse than 21st since 2006. He also missed a game for the first time since 2010. Now 36 years old, Gore won't see enough volume to allow consistent fantasy production. Even if Singletary were to miss time, Gore would share touches with TJ Yeldon. There's little fantasy appeal here.

name: DK Metcalf
weekly_outlook: The Seahawks selected Metcalf with the final pick of the second round of April's draft. Metcalf is huge (6-foot-3, 228 pounds) with terrific explosiveness, speed and downfield play-making ability. The former Ole Miss star is young (he turns 22 in December) and raw, the latter of which can somewhat be attributed to injury woes. Metcalf showed off his speed and size at the combine with a 4.33 40-yard dash and 27 bench reps, though he did raise major red flags by struggling in quickness events. Metcalf has the upside to become one of the league's next premiere vertical receivers, especially with Russell Wilson on the other end of the battery, but he figures to be more boom/bust than a consistent producer as a situational deep threat in Seattle's super-run-heavy offense in 2019.

name: Duke Johnson
weekly_outlook: Johnson has emerged as one of the league's best receiving backs since he was drafted in the third round of the 2015 draft. He ranks third at the position in targets (297), third in receptions (235), first in receiving yards (2170) and 11th in touchdown catches (eight) the past four seasons. Despite the success, Johnson had career lows in carries (40) and targets (62) last season. Fantasy's No. 11 scoring back in 2017 plummeted to a career-worst 37th in 2018. A bounceback figures to be in the cards in 2019 as Johnson was traded to Houston where he'll play a major role following Lamar Miller's torn ACL. Johnson figures to be limited a bit as a rusher, but will certainly be very busy as Houston's primary receiving back. He's in the RB2 mix.

name: Jason Witten
weekly_outlook: Witten has come out of retirement and is back at the top of the depth chart in Dallas. When we last saw Witten, he was an every-down player and handled a solid 5.4 targets per game back in 2017. Primarily utilized as a sure-handed, short-area target who offers little after the catch, Witten finished 33rd at the position in fantasy points per snap. Of course, Witten led all tight ends with 897 snaps and, because volume is king, he managed a ninth-place finish in fantasy points. Witten is now 37 years old and expected to play more of a situational role in 2019. He hasn't posted a fantasy season better than ninth since 2013 and that's unlikely to change this season. He's a back-end TE2.

name: Geronimo Allison
weekly_outlook: Following a nondescript first two NFL seasons, Allison appeared on his way to a breakout 2018 season. Healthy and operating as Green Bay's No. 3 wide receiver during Weeks 1-4, Allison posted a 19/289/2 line and was fantasy's No. 28 scorer at the position. Allison has registered only 55 catches in 30 career games, but his strong 2018 efficiency (67 percent catch rate, 10.1 YPT) and the Packers' shaky depth chart positions him well for a run at No. 2 duties opposite Davante Adams. In that scenario, Allison would, at least, be on the flex radar. He's an intriguing mid-round flier.

name: Demaryius Thomas
weekly_outlook: Thomas signed with the Patriots, which breathes some life into a career that appeared to be closing in on the end. Since peaking with a 111/1619/11 line in 2014, Thomas' production has progressively dipped each of the past four seasons. He was shipped to Houston at last year's trade deadline before tearing an Achilles in December. Despite the late-season injury, Thomas is healthy and ready to go for Week 1. The 31-year-old could find himself in the flex conversation if he returns to form, but the presence of Julian Edelman and Josh Gordon in a run-first offense figures to limit the veteran to inconsistent production.

name: Miles Boykin
weekly_outlook: Boykin was the second of two wide receivers selected by Baltimore during April's draft. Unlike small and speedy first-rounder Marquise Brown, third-rounder Boykin stands 6-foot-4, 220 pounds and is a terrific athlete with serious length similar to Kenny Golladay. The Notre Dame product was a huge winner at the combine, posting outstanding marks in the 40-yard dash (4.42), three-cone drill (6.77), short shuttle (4.07) and broad jump (140 inches). Boykin doesn't add much after the catch (3.8 RAC last season), but he'll quickly be able to step in as a perimeter deep threat opposite Brown, with Willie Snead manning the slot. Baltimore's run-heavy attack and Lamar Jackson's shaky accuracy figure to crush his 2019 fantasy stock, but Boykin is an intriguing prospect, so stash him in dynasty.

name: George Kittle
weekly_outlook: After showing flashes of his massive ceiling as a fifth-round rookie in 2017, Kittle exploded for a tight-end record 1,377 receiving yards last season. The Iowa product also ranked first at the position RAC (9.7) and was third in targets (136), receptions (88), fantasy points (259) and YPR (15.6). The only area where Kittle was truly underwhelming was in the scoring department, as he managed only five touchdowns (5.8 OTD) and seven end-zone targets. The future is bright for the 25-year-old Kittle, who will sustain a massive target share in the 49ers' improving offense. Scoop him up in the third round of your draft.

name: Carson Wentz
weekly_outlook: Wentz came back to earth last season following a breakout 2017 campaign in which he tossed 33 touchdowns and seven interceptions in 13 games prior to tearing his ACL. Wentz, who was third in fantasy points per game in 2017, fell to 17th last season during the 11 weeks he was active. On the plus side, Wentz finished top 15 in yards per attempt for the second season in a row and improved his completion rate from 60 to 70 percent (fourth best). Likely related to his ACL recovery but still notable, Wentz's rushing production plummeted (93 yards on 34 carries). Wentz has the support of a great offensive line and now has DeSean Jackson, JJ Arcega-Whiteside and Jordan Howard in his arsenal. He is best valued as a good QB2, but has huge upside.

name: Kyler Murray
weekly_outlook: Murray was the first overall selection in April's draft and a strong favorite to open 2019 as Arizona's starter. The Oklahoma product is extremely undersized (5-foot-10, 207 pounds), but exceptionally efficient with his arm (he set an FBS record with an 11.6 YPA last season) and highly productive with his legs (1,001 rushing yards while averaging 7.2 YPC last season). There have been only three top-10 and six top-14 fantasy seasons by rookie quarterbacks over the past decade, but all who accomplished that did a lot of damage with their legs -- an area in which Murray will shine. Rookies are always risks, but Murray's skill set and path to snaps means he should be viewed as a QB2 with QB1 upside. He's worth a late-round pick in your draft.

name: Michael Gallup
weekly_outlook: All eyes are on Amari Cooper in Dallas, but don't overlook the guy lined up opposite him. Gallup -- a third-round pick last season -- played a situational role early on in 2018, but took over as a full-timer just prior to the acquisition of Cooper. Gallup played 77 percent of Dallas' snaps from Week 6 forward and, though he was a minimal fantasy contributor, he certainly showed flashes. Gallup's 14.1 aDOT (13th highest), 5.1 RAC (22nd), 15.4 YPR (12th) all ranked near the top of the league, though he dealt with 31 percent of balls thrown his way registering as off target (sixth-highest). The 23-year-old is an intriguing prospect who figures to be no lower than third in line for targets in a good offense. Take a mid-to-late-round flier.

name: Miles Sanders
weekly_outlook: The Eagles selected Sanders in the third round of April's draft. He joins fellow newcomer Jordan Howard atop the Philadelphia depth chart. Saquon Barkley's replacement at Penn State racked up 220 carries in 2018 and was one of the nation's most elusive backs, evading one tackler for every 6.4 touches. Sanders is shifty and agile, but not especially explosive and he's struggled with fumbles (five last season). Sanders checks in at 5-foot-11, 211 pounds and is a solid receiver and kick returner (which also fills a void for the Eagles). He had a very good combine, which was highlighted by a 4.49 40-yard dash and position-best 6.89 three cone. Sanders' shiftiness makes him a terrific complement to between-the-tackles bruiser Howard. Expect the two to split carries, with Howard the primary goal-line back and Sanders busier in passing situations. Sanders is a fringe top-25 fantasy back.

name: Jamison Crowder
weekly_outlook: Crowder joins the Jets after spending his first four seasons in Washington. Crowder aligned inside on 77 percent of his routes during four seasons with Washington and will operate between Robby Anderson and Quincy Enunwa in New York. Crowder cleared 65 receptions and 780 receiving yards in both 2016 and 2017, posting his best fantasy campaign (26th) during the former, but missed seven games due to injury in 2018. Extremely undersized, the 5-foot-8, 185-pound Crowder has 14 touchdowns (13.3 OTD) in 56 career games, seven of which came during the aforementioned 2016 season. New Jets head coach Adam Gase has made good use of his receivers, which adds to Crowder's fantasy appeal. He's a fine target in the middle rounds, but downgrade him in non-PPR leagues.

name: T.J. Hockenson
weekly_outlook: Detroit selected Hockenson eighth overall in April's draft. The Iowa product joins free-agent signing Jesse James atop the Lions' depth chart. Hockenson is a terrific pass catcher and good blocker who has drawn comparisons to Travis Kelce, Rob Gronkowski and even former Hawkeye George Kittle. Hockenson is a superb athlete, with good size (6-foot-5, 251 pounds) and toughness. He crushed it at the combine, placing near the top of the position in all but the bench press. Hockenson has every-down tight end written all over him, but, as is usual for rookie tight ends, he figures to learn the ropes in 2019 before emerging as a fantasy threat in 2020. Hockenson doesn't need to be on your radar in 10-team leagues in 2019.

name: Adrian Peterson
weekly_outlook: Peterson's 2018 prospects seemed dim during most of last offseason, but Derrius Guice's torn ACL allowed the former fantasy star one more shot at lead back duties. Peterson held down the fort, finishing fifth in the league with 251 carries and averaging 4.2 yards per carry. As usual, Peterson played a minimal role as a receiver (26 targets) but scored enough touchdowns (eight) to manage a 19th-place finish in fantasy points. Peterson re-signed with Washington, but with Guice healthy and ready to roll, the 2018 second-round pick will be the team's primary back. The 34-year-old Peterson will have flex value only if Guice misses time.

name: Mason Crosby
weekly_outlook: Crosby was fantasy's No. 7 kicker in 2018 after finishing 16th or worse each of the previous three seasons. He attempted 37 field goals, which tied for his second most in a single season in his 12-year career. Crosby has benefited from plenty of opportunity in Green Bay's high-scoring offense, but efficiency has eluded him nearly his entire career. He made 30 of 37 attempts last season (81.1 percent) and, in terms of expected conversion rate based on distance, Crosby has been below average in nine of 12 seasons, including each of the past three. Crosby is a fringe fantasy starter and loses some value in leagues that dock for misses.

name: Jimmy Garoppolo
weekly_outlook: To this point, the Garoppolo experiment has not worked out for San Francisco. The former Patriot was acquired during the 2017 season, but has appeared in only nine games due to injury. In fact, the 27-year-old has yet to appear in more than six games in a regular season. Garoppolo's play has also left something to be desired. In nine games with the 49ers, he's contributed 13 touchdowns, thrown 8 interceptions and fumbled 5 times. His production is almost exactly identical to that posted by 2017 undrafted free agent Nick Mullens in eight games last season. Garoppolo remains a bit of an unknown, but his combination of talent and the presence of head coach Kyle Shanahan offers him fantasy upside. He's a back-end QB2 and post-hype sleeper.

name: Ted Ginn Jr.
weekly_outlook: After posting a pair of top-35 fantasy seasons during the previous three seasons, Ginn appeared on his way to another in 2018 prior to suffering a Week 4 knee injury. Through three weeks, Ginn's 12/135/2 line was enough to allow him the 40th-most fantasy points at the position. He had been on the field for 74 percent of New Orleans' pass plays, which was his highest rate since 2009. Ginn led all wide receivers with a 77 percent catch rate in 2017. He's now 34 years old and second-year Tre'Quan Smith looms, but Ginn could push for flex production if he picks up where he left off in last season's playoffs as the No. 2 wide receiver in the Saints' high-scoring offense.

name: Kalen Ballage
weekly_outlook: A 2018 fourth-round pick, Ballage was limited to 23 snaps through Week 14 of his rookie season. With Frank Gore sidelined, Ballage shared backfield duties with Kenyan Drake during Miami's final three games. Results varied, with Ballage showing his playmaking ability with a 75-yard touchdown run but otherwise managing 3.3 YPC (1.6 YAC) on his other 35 attempts. Ballage was limited to 56 yards on 11 targets (5.1 YPT). The boom/bust production aligns with Ballage's profile, as he made the occasional big play at Arizona State, but his overall efficiency was about as poor as you'll find. Kenyan Drake is the top dog in Miami, but Ballage is worth a late flier as a second-year, 23-year-old back on the roster of a rebuilding team.

name: Joe Flacco
weekly_outlook: Flacco heads to Denver where he takes over as the Broncos' starter, though it's not clear that he's actually an upgrade on Case Keenum. Flacco posted the league's eighth-worst completion percentage (61 percent) and fifth-worst yards per attempt (6.5) in 2018. In fact, his 6.3 YPA over the past four seasons is worst among 38 qualified passers. Incredibly, Flacco has never finished a season better than 10th in fantasy points and his last finish better than 20th came in 2014. Flacco has struggled with efficiency for years, is now 34 years old, offers the bare minimum with his legs, has an unproven supporting cast and figures to lose some late-season starts to Drew Lock. Flacco is not worth drafting in most formats.

name: Adam Shaheen
weekly_outlook: The Bears drafted Shaheen in the second round of the 2017 draft, but the massive 6-foot-6, 278-pound tight end has little fantasy appeal as the blocking complement to Trey Burton. Shaheen missed 10 games last season and handled a grand total of seven targets during the six games he was active. Shaheen could surprise with a half dozen touchdowns, but, barring a Burton injury, simply won't see enough volume to land on the fantasy radar.

name: Zach Ertz
weekly_outlook: Ertz set the all-time tight end record with 116 receptions last season and was fantasy's No. 2 scorer at the position. Incredibly, Ertz has improved his fantasy point total each of his seasons in the NFL and has now posted four consecutive top-nine finishes. He paced all tight ends in snaps (949), routes (550) and targets (156), while ranking top-four in receiving yards (1,163), touchdowns (eight) and end-zone targets (nine) last season. After struggling in the area during his first four seasons, Ertz has scored exactly eight touchdowns in back-to-back seasons. The 28-year-old is an elite, high-floor fantasy option who could defer some targets to DeSean Jackson and Dallas Goedert and still post a top-three fantasy season. He'll cost you a third-round pick this season.

name: Mark Ingram II
weekly_outlook: Ingram joins the Ravens after an eight-year stint in New Orleans. Following a slow start to his career, Ingram has averaged 4.73 YPC, including 2.10 after contact, the past six seasons. Those marks rank first and second, respectively, among 31 backs with 650 carries in that span. Ingram ranks second in the league in rushing touchdowns (39), second in rushing OTD (37.5) and tied for first in carries inside the opponent's 5-yard line (61) the past five seasons. The 29-year-old Ingram is a strong bet to pace the extremely run-heavy Ravens' backfield in carries and possibly targets. Ingram has a real shot to eclipse his previous career-high carry total of 230 (2017). He's a flex option who can be upgraded slightly in non-PPR.

name: Mark Andrews
weekly_outlook: Andrews was the second tight end drafted by Baltimore last season, but that didn't stop the Oklahoma product from producing one of the best seasons by a rookie tight end over the past decade. Andrews' 552 receiving yards rank sixth, and his 16.2 YPR, 10.0 YPT and 10.4 aDOT all rank second among rookie tight ends since 2007. Andrews did all that damage despite playing only 35 percent of the snaps. Andrews' future looks bright, but he'll need to find ways to stay on the field with 2018 first-round pick Hayden Hurst and re-signed blocker Nick Boyle also on the roster. Andrews is a fine late-round flier, but Baltimore's run-heavy offense will limit his upside.

name: Alshon Jeffery
weekly_outlook: Jeffery has posted a pair of solid fantasy seasons since joining the Eagles, but he has done it two different ways. In 2017, a massive 28 percent of balls thrown his direction were off target, which led to an ugly 48 percent catch rate. He still posted a 57/789/9 line and finished 21st in fantasy points. In 2018, Jeffery missed three games and was targeted closer to the line of scrimmage more often, which allowed a healthy 71 percent catch rate and 65/840/6 line. Jeffery was fantasy's No. 17 WR after returning in Week 4. The rangy receiver has reached double digits in end zone targets during each of the past six seasons and is the top perimeter option in a strong Eagles' offense. The 29-year-old is a solid WR2.

name: Jack Doyle
weekly_outlook: Fellow tight end Eric Ebron stole the headlines last season, but it was Doyle, not Ebron,  who was (and still is) the Colts' No. 1 tight end. Doyle missed 10 games due to a pair of injuries, but during the six games both he and Ebron were active, Doyle ran 151 routes and was targeted 33 times, compared to 101 routes and 22 targets for Ebron. Doyle posted a 26-245-2 line and was fantasy's No. 6 tight end during those six weeks. Sure-handed Doyle has ranked top five in catch rate each of the past five seasons, though he does nearly all of his damage in the short area (5.0 career aDOT). Doyle caught 80 passes in 15 games with Jacoby Brissett under center in 2017, so it's fair to expect that connection to pick up where it left off in 2019. Consider the 29-year-old Doyle a fringe TE1 in PPR and more of a TE2 in non-PPR.

name: Trey Quinn
weekly_outlook: Last season's Mr. Irrelevant, Quinn was the final pick of the 2018 draft. Two injuries derailed his rookie campaign, but Quinn did flash in his only two full games. He posted a 9/75/1 line on 10 targets and was fantasy's No. 33 wide receiver. Quinn is the in-house favorite to replace Jamison Crowder as Washington's slot receiver between Terry McLaurin and Paul Richardson. The durability concerns of Richardson and Jordan Reed, combined with McLaurin's inexperience, open the door for Quinn to sneak into a big role in his second season. He's an intriguing sleeper in deep PPR leagues.

name: Phillip Lindsay
weekly_outlook: Lindsay entered the 2018 season as a notable combine snub who signed on with Denver as an undrafted free agent. It didn't take him long to become one of the league's most explosive playmakers. Lindsay averaged 5.4 YPC (sixth-highest) on 192 attempts and finished 13th among backs in fantasy points. Although Lindsay's explosiveness can't be overlooked, there were some red flags. He benefited from 3.82 yards before contact per attempt (second-highest), averaged 1.58 after contact (14th-worst), averaged 5.0 yards per target (sixth-worst) and saw his YPC plummet to 2.6 in his final three games. It's possible that we've already seen Lindsay's ceiling, as he turns 25 years old this summer, but he is set for a significant role along with fellow second-year back Royce Freeman this season. Lindsay figures to return to earth a bit, but he's still in the RB2 discussion.

name: Matt Breida
weekly_outlook: Breida went undrafted in 2017 but received significant hype leading into his rookie season. He has lived up to it, averaging 5.0 YPC on 258 career carries, including 5.3 YPC in 2018 (seventh-best). Breida stepped up his game as a receiver in 2018, catching 84 percent of his targets (fifth-best) and averaging 8.2 yards per target (third-best) on 32 targets. Breida is on the small side at 5-foot-11, 190 pounds, which has led to a limited role near the goal line (five rushing touchdowns and seven carries inside the 5 in his career). If there's a red flag here, it's Breida's poor post-contact production (career 1.62 YAC). Breida has been effective, but he'll need to share the 49er's backfield with Tevin Coleman in 2019. That leaves the 24-year-old as more of a fringe flex option.

name: Darrell Henderson Jr.
weekly_outlook: The Rams traded up and selected Henderson in the third round of April's draft. A master in rushing efficiency, Henderson averaged an astounding 8.88 yards per carry on 130 attempts in 2017 before improving to 8.92 YPC on 214 carries in 2018. The Memphis product averaged 6.0 yards after contact per attempt last season, which is higher than the yards per carry of all but five of the backs who attended the combine. Henderson is small (5-foot-8, 208 pounds) but elusive and has decent speed (4.49 40-yard dash). Henderson likely won't have standalone fantasy value as long as Todd Gurley (even if he's scaled back a bit) is healthy, but he's certainly a very valuable handcuff, especially considering Gurley struggled through the latter part of last season with a knee injury. Henderson belongs on the bench in most leagues.

name: Nelson Agholor
weekly_outlook: Agholor's 2017 season felt like a success and his 2018 a disappointment, but his production was closer than you probably realize. The 2015 first-round pick posted a 62/768/8 line during a breakout 2017 season, but his 5.0 OTD suggested touchdown regression to the mean was on tap. Sure enough, the Eagles slot receiver posted a similar 64/743/4 line in 2018 with touchdowns being the notable exception. Agholor still managed a 34th-place finish in fantasy points (he was 23rd in 2017), though half of his four weekly finishes better than 38th came in Weeks 16-17. The 26-year-old still has a role in a good Eagles offense, but he has a lot of competition for targets with DeSean Jackson and J.J. Arcega-Whiteside now in the fold and Dallas Goedert entering his second season. Agholor is fine bench depth, but not a weekly starter.

name: Randall Cobb
weekly_outlook: Cobb signed with the Cowboys after spending the first eight seasons of his career with the Packers. Cobb peaked with a 91/1287/12 line (WR8 in fantasy) in 2014, but his production has progressively dropped over the past four seasons. Injuries have been a problem throughout Cobb's career, as he has managed only two 16-game regular seasons and has missed 11 games over the past three seasons. Solely a short-area target, Cobb has ranked near the bottom of the league in aDOT in each of his eight seasons. He'll replace Cole Beasley in the slot in Dallas and doesn't figure to offer many big downfield plays or touchdowns. Likely fourth in line for targets, the 28-year-old Cobb is only worth a late-round flier.

name: Adam Vinatieri
weekly_outlook: Vinatieri missed one game last season, but still finished 13th in fantasy points and registered eight top-10 weeks (tied for third most). The future Hall of Famer's production has been inconsistent in recent seasons, as he's finished four of his past nine seasons as a top-five fantasy kicker, but 13th or worse the other five seasons. His production was better when Andrew Luck was under center, which hurts his cause in 2019. It's also fair to wonder if Vinatieri's play has slipped a bit, as he's converted only 85.3 percent of his field goal attempts over the past two seasons (he was at 90.7 percent the previous four seasons). Nonetheless, the 46-year-old is back for his 25th NFL season and is best-viewed as a starter only in 16-team leagues.

name: Dawson Knox
weekly_outlook: The Bills drafted Knox in the third round of April's draft. He joins blocker Tyler Kroft to form a revamped TE duo in Buffalo. An intriguing pass-catching prospect, Knox essentially played wide receiver at Ole Miss, aligning in the slot on 80 percent of his 195 routes in 2018. Knox has terrific size (6-foot-4, 254 pounds) and athleticism, but isn't overly fast or quick. He was underutilized during his Ole Miss days, but was still highly efficient when targeted. He paced tight end prospects in YPR (18.9), aDOT (11.4) and first-down rate (80 percent) in 2018, while also averaging 8.7 yards after the catch (second best). Incredibly, Knox failed to catch a single touchdown in 22 games at Ole Miss. He may lead Bills tight ends in targets this season, but is unlikely to land on the fantasy radar.

name: Bears D/ST
weekly_outlook: The Bears entered the 2018 season with arguably the league's best defense on paper, and boy, did they deliver. Fantasy's top-scoring D/ST (55 points more than second place) paced the NFL in interceptions (27), D/ST touchdowns (six), passes defensed (92) and points allowed (283). They ranked third in sacks with 50. Chicago lost Adrian Amos and Bryce Callahan in free agency but remains stocked with star talent on every level, led by the likes of Akiem Hicks, Khalil Mack, Kyle Fuller, Danny Trevathan and Eddie Jackson. The addition of star returner Cordarrelle Patterson (league-high four kick return touchdowns since 2014) adds to the appeal. This elite unit should be the first off the board in 2019 fantasy drafts.

name: Devonta Freeman
weekly_outlook: Freeman enters his sixth NFL season after missing all but 64 snaps due to injury last season. Of course, he posted stellar numbers in each of his previous three seasons. The 2014 fourth-round pick paced the position in fantasy points in 2015, finished sixth in 2016 and ranked ninth in the 13 weeks he was active and healthy in 2017. Freeman's efficiency has been good, but where he really stands out is volume near the goal line. He rushed for 29 touchdowns from 2015 to 2017, thanks to 41 carries inside the opponent's 5-yard line (second-most). He finished top-five in the category all three seasons and scored six touchdown receptions in that span. Tevin Coleman is gone, which helps solidify the 27-year-old's standing as a solid RB2 with RB1 upside.

name: Kenny Golladay
weekly_outlook: The Lions turned to a run-first scheme and struggled with efficiency last season, but that didn't stop Golladay from enjoying a breakout season. The 2017 third-round pick exploded for a 70/1063/5 line despite 25 percent of balls thrown his way registering as off target (15th highest). Golladay was limited to two top 10 fantasy weeks and his touchdown total leaves something to be desired (6.0 OTD), but he still managed to put together a 21st-place finish in fantasy points in 15 games. The 25-year-old is, at least, a fringe WR2 and there's upside for more in his third NFL season.

name: Carlos Hyde
weekly_outlook: Hyde is now with Houston after a disappointing 2018 campaign in which he managed only 571 yards on 172 carries (3.3 YPC) and 33 yards on 10 catches (2.1 YPT) in 14 games with Cleveland and Jacksonville. Although the 27-year-old's efficiency has dipped after an explosive start to his career, Hyde has often ranked near the top of the league in stacked boxes (76th percentile or higher in average box defenders in four of his five seasons) and quietly posted a solid 1.9 YAC last season. Hyde has a path to consistent carries with only Duke Johnson Jr. in his way in Houston and, though he isn't an effective receiver, flex value is within range if he locks down 13-to-15 carries per game. He's worth a late-round flier.

name: Broncos D/ST
weekly_outlook: Denver's D/ST is fantasy's reigning No. 10 unit and has finished no lower than 13th the past seven seasons. The unit jumped to fifth in interceptions (17), eighth in sacks (44) and first in blocks (four), though it was 22nd in yardage allowed (5,842) last season. This unit lost a lot of solid talent in the offseason (Bradley Roby, Brandon Marshall, Shaq Barrett, Shane Ray, Darian Stewart) but brought in defensive-minded coach Vic Fangio and improved its secondary with Bryce Callahan and Kareem Jackson. A potentially lethal pass rush led by Von Miller, Bradley Chubb and Derek Wolfe, as well as stud corner Chris Harris Jr. keeps this D/ST in the top-10 mix.

name: Trey Burton
weekly_outlook: Burton finished his first season in Chicago as fantasy's No. 8 scoring tight end, but inconsistent usage and production left many who invested in the popular 2018 sleeper underwhelmed. Burton failed to clear four targets in eight of his first 11 games. He posted a top-10 week in 25 percent of his outings (15th highest) and finished 30th or worse five times (including four straight during Weeks 11-14). Burton did score six touchdowns, but his 3.6 OTD and four end-zone targets suggest he was over his head in that department. On the plus side, Burton finished strong with a target share of at least 17 percent during each of the team's final four regular-season games. The 27-year-old is a TE2.

name: Tyler Eifert
weekly_outlook: Eifert has been a fantasy force when healthy, but that hasn't been the case much during his six seasons in the league. The 2013 first-round pick has never appeared in a full 16-game regular season, managing to play only 43 (or 45 percent) of a possible 96 games. Eifert missed three games in 2015 but still led the league with 13 touchdowns. He missed eight games in 2016 but scored five touchdowns and ranked seventh at the position in fantasy points per game. In 2018, Eifert posted back-to-back top-seven fantasy weeks before going down with an ankle injury after four games. Eifert's durability is obviously a major concern, but the 28-year-old has enough upside to warrant a late-round flier in deeper leagues.

name: Albert Wilson
weekly_outlook: Wilson suffered a hip injury in Week 7 last season, which derailed what was likely to be a breakout campaign for the 2014 undrafted receiver. Wilson threw a 52 yard touchdown and posted a 26/391/4 receiving line en route to sitting as fantasy's No. 25 scoring wideout through Week 7. Wilson averaged 13.3 yards after the catch, which was second-best at the position. Miami's depth chart is wide open, which positions Wilson for a generous target share in an offense now led by Ryan Fitzpatrick and Josh Rosen. This offense doesn't figure to score often, but an every-down role for the explosive 27-year-old would make him a deep sleeper option.

name: Case Keenum
weekly_outlook: Keenum was traded to Washington after holding down the fort while playing all but one snap in Denver last season. The results weren't particularly impressive, as Keenum completed 62 percent of his passes (10th worst) and posted 6.6 yards per attempt (sixth worst). Despite ranking seventh in dropbacks, he was held to one top-12 fantasy week and finished 19th in total fantasy points at the position. The 31-year-old is a fringe NFL starter and will have his hands full holding off first-round pick Dwayne Haskins all season. Keenum isn't a good fantasy option.

name: Gus Edwards
weekly_outlook: A relatively unheralded prospect, Edwards went undrafted in 2018 before eventually storming onto the fantasy scene around midseason. From Week 11 on, Edwards averaged 17.4 carries per game, though he was targeted only once. On 137 carries for the season, Edwards averaged 5.2 YPC (eighth-best), including 2.1 YAC (17th-best). Edwards scored only two touchdowns, and his nonexistent receiving role limited him to one weekly fantasy finish better than 19th. Edwards is now behind Mark Ingram II on the depth chart and, though he could still push for more than 100 carries in Baltimore's run-heavy offense, he won't see many (any?) targets and, thus, is no more than a low-ceiling Ingram handcuff.

name: Hunter Renfrow
weekly_outlook: Despite a very shaky group of wide receivers, the Raiders ranked 18th in three-plus wide receiver sets last season (76%). In coach Jon Gruden and OC Greg Olson's second season with the team, we should expect that number to rise with Tyrell Williams, J.J. Nelson, Ryan Grant and Renfrow added to the fold. Renfrow was selected by Oakland in the fifth round of April's draft. The 5-foot-10, 184-pound Clemson product has a path to a significant rookie season role with the team's slot gig up for grabs and only Williams clearly ahead in target priority. Renfrow is an underrated dynasty hold and could sneak into value in PPR leagues in 2019.

name: Matt Ryan
weekly_outlook: Perhaps one of the league's most underrated players, Ryan has ranked ninth or better in completions, passing yards and completion percentage each of the past seven seasons. Last season, Ryan finished second at the position in fantasy points for the second time in three seasons. He will be reunited with offensive coordinator Dirk Koetter. Ryan finished top five in the NFL in passing yards during each of Koetter's previous three seasons with Atlanta (2012-14). Ryan doesn't add much with his legs (though he did add three rushing scores along with 35 passing touchdowns last season), but he's never short on top-end volume and efficiency. Especially with a terrific wide receiver trio and solid offensive line, Ryan is positioned for another top-five fantasy campaign.

name: Kerryon Johnson
weekly_outlook: Johnson was one of the youngest players selected in the 2018 draft, but that didn't stop the Auburn product from making an immediate impact. Despite playing only 51 percent of the snaps, Johnson ranked 14th among running backs in fantasy points prior to suffering a season-ending injury in Week 11. Johnson averaged 5.4 YPC (fifth-best) and caught 84 percent (seventh-best) of his 38 targets. Johnson will defer some touches to C.J. Anderson and PJ Johnson this season, but his averages of 12.5 carries and 4.0 targets per game after Week 1 last season will suffice to allow him RB2 production. Plus, there's room for more if he continues to play at a high level and with Theo Riddick gone. Johnson is a solid RB2 and breakout candidate.

name: Larry Fitzgerald
weekly_outlook: A future Hall of Famer, Fitzgerald will return for his 16th NFL season. The 2004 first-round pick posted three-consecutive seasons with at least 107 receptions and 1,023 yards prior to regressing in 2018, when he posted a 69/734/6 line and finished 25th in fantasy points. In addition, he managed only two top-20 fantasy weeks. Quarterback play was an obvious issue, helping Fitzgerald to a 6.6 YPT, which was ninth-worst at the position and his worst mark in the category since 2012. It's possible Kliff Kingsbury's modern offense can help Fitzgerald to a rebound season, but it's hard to see a ton of upside for a 36-year-old receiver, especially after Arizona drafted three wide receivers. Fitzgerald is best-viewed as a flex option.

name: Damien Williams
weekly_outlook: Williams entered 2018 as an afterthought following four nondescript seasons in Miami in which he averaged an ugly 3.6 YPC on 133 carries and 6.5 yards per play on 112 targets. Williams barely played in the first half of the 2018 season, but Kareem Hunt's release led to a huge opportunity for him. He didn't disappoint, producing 352 yards and six touchdown on 60 touches in Weeks 14-17. Only two backs scored more fantasy points in the stretch. It's fair to be a bit suspicious of the now-27-year-old Williams after the small sample of success, especially after the team signed LeSean McCoy, but Williams still could lead the high-scoring Chiefs in touches out of the backfield. Williams was way overpriced during most 2019 fantasy drafts, but still could settle in as a flex.

name: Terry McLaurin
weekly_outlook: The Redskins drafted McLaurin in the third round of April's draft, adding the Ohio State product to a wide receiver room that also includes Paul Richardson, Kelvin Harmon and Trey Quinn. McLaurin is an older prospect (he turned 23 in April) with an average frame (6-foot, 208 pounds) who is extremely fast (4.35 40-yard dash). An efficient receiver, the former Buckeye averaged 14.3 yards per target last season, which topped this class. McLaurin could settle in as a depth receiver and special-teams standout, but he has a terrific opportunity for a major rookie-season role because of Washington's shaky depth chart. That puts him on the late-round radar in deeper leagues.

name: Devin Singletary
weekly_outlook: The Bills selected Singletary in the third round of April's draft. Singletary is very undersized (5-foot-7, 203 pounds) and lacks home run speed (4.66 40-yard dash), but makes up for that with toughness and elusiveness. The Florida Atlantic star ran for 22 touchdowns and ranked among the top backs in the class in broken tackle rate and evaded tackle rate in 2018. Singletary can contribute as a receiver and is a strong pass-blocker. Following the offseason release of LeSean McCoy, the rookie is positioned for a big role ahead of Frank Gore and TJ Yeldon. Take a shot on Singletary in the middle rounds.

name: Robby Anderson
weekly_outlook: Expectations were high for Anderson entering last season following a breakout 2017 campaign in which he busted out for a 63/941/7 line. Things didn't go well early, as Anderson was limited to 5.25 targets per game and was fantasy's No. 59 wide receiver during Weeks 1-9. Life improved once Sam Darnold returned from injury, however, as Anderson's targets jumped to 10.0 per game and he was fantasy's No. 7 WR during Weeks 14-17. Anderson has ranked 19th in YPR each of the past two seasons and has posted a top 3 aDOT in two of his three NFL seasons. The vertical threat is in his prime years at 26 and has upside as second-year Darnold's top target. He's a fringe WR3.

name: Titans D/ST
weekly_outlook: Tennessee entered 2018 with one of the league's best defenses on paper, and it showed. The Titans allowed 303 points (third-fewest) and 5,334 yards (eighth-fewest) en route to posting their first top-10 D/ST fantasy campaign since 2008. Despite the improvements, Tennessee ranked 23rd in interceptions (11) and hasn't finished better than 15th in forced turnovers since the aforementioned 2008 season. The edge rush took a beating during the offseason with Derrick Morgan, Brian Orakpo and Will Compton departing but remains in solid shape with addition Cameron Wake and second-year Harold Landry. They join the likes of Jurrell Casey, Jayon Brown, Wesley Woodyard, Kevin Byard, Adoree' Jackson and first-round pick Jeffery Simmons to form a very good defense. Consider this a fringe starting D/ST.

name: Nyheim Hines
weekly_outlook: As fourth-round draft picks go, Hines had a good rookie season. The scat back was limited to 85 carries and four offensive touchdowns but ranked top-10 among backs in pass routes (294), targets (81), receptions (63) and average depth of target (2.3). He finished 27th in fantasy points but managed only one weekly finish better than 18th. Hines' role allowed some fantasy relevance, but he struggled with efficiency, with his 3.7 YPC, 1.5 YAC and 5.2 YPT all ranking near the bottom of the position. Hines is positioned for a similar role in a Colts' offense that will need to throw more than expected with Andrew Luck gone. Hines is a PPR flex in deeper leagues.

name: Giovani Bernard
weekly_outlook: Bernard has been one of the league's best receiving backs since he entered the league in 2013, but his role has diminished in recent seasons as a result of injuries (10 missed games the past three seasons) and the emergence of workhorse Joe Mixon. Bernard posted career-low marks in both carries (56) and receptions (35) last season. His 4.7 YPT was second-worst at the position and marks the first time in six seasons that he didn't finish top-20 in the category. Undersized and uninvolved near the goal line, Bernard hasn't cleared four touchdowns in a season since 2014. He is no more than a backup who steals some passing-down work from Mixon. His primary value is as a handcuff.

name: DaeSean Hamilton
weekly_outlook: A 2018 fourth-round pick, Hamilton played sparingly throughout most of his rookie season, but Emmanuel Sanders' season-ending torn Achilles in Week 13 vaulted the Penn State product into a larger role. After totaling seven targets in his first 10 games, Hamilton handled eight-plus targets during each of Denver's final four games spanning Weeks 14-17. Hamilton was fantasy's No. 22 WR during the span. He primarily lined up in the slot and worked as a short-area target (8.4 aDOT), which allowed a 67 percent catch rate, but only two touchdowns and an ugly 5.4 YPT. The 24-year-old enters his second season with a legitimate path to consistent targets as Denver's primary slot receiver. Hamilton is a solid mid-to-late round flier.

name: Andy Isabella
weekly_outlook: The Cardinals selected Isabella in the second round of April's draft. The 5-foot-9, 188-pound receiver out of UMASS is undersized, but also quick, strong and fast. Like Julian Edelman, he's extremely versatile, with the ability to play inside and out, while adding value as a rusher and returner. Like Brandin Cooks, he has the vertical speed (4.31 40-yard dash) to make plays deep downfield. Isabella led the nation with 1,698 receiving yards, ranked second in catches (102) and finished sixth with 13 touchdown catches in 2018. He'll battle with fellow rookie KeeSean Johnson for work behind Christian Kirk and Larry Fitzgerald in 2019. Barring a terrific season from first overall pick Kyler Murray, Isabella figures to struggle to push for flex value as a rookie, but he has WR2 upside down the road.

name: Hayden Hurst
weekly_outlook: Baltimore selected Hurst in the first round of the 2018 draft, but the rookie played sparingly after missing the first month of the season with an injury. Hurst was limited to 106 pass routes and caught 13 of 23 targets for 163 yards and one touchdown. Hurst is an obvious candidate for a leap forward in his second NFL season, but he was outplayed by fellow second-year TE Mark Andrews in 2018, and Baltimore signed Nick Boyle to an extension to play a big role as a blocker. That leaves Hurst without a clear path to targets in the league's run-heaviest offense. Hurst, who turns 26 years old this year, is best as a dynasty hold.

name: David Moore
weekly_outlook: Moore was an unheralded seventh-round draft pick in 2017 and played sparingly during his first season and a half in the NFL. The East Central product took on a larger role near midseason in 2018 and went on to post a 26/445/5 line on 293 routes. Moore was primarily utilized as a vertical threat (his 15.4 aDOT ranked seventh), which allowed him a 17.1 YPR (fourth highest). Moore also racked up 11 end zone targets, which ranked 17th at the position. The 6-foot-2, 225-pound perimeter receiver will miss the early portion of the 2019 season due to injury and  will be hard to trust in Seattle's run-heavy offense even when healthy. That's especially the case after the team drafted DK Metcalf.

name: Charles Clay
weekly_outlook: Clay signed with the Cardinals following a disappointing four-year tenure in Buffalo. Clay broke out way back in 2013, when he posted a 69-759-6 line and was fantasy's No. 8 tight end. Since that point, he's missed at least one game in five consecutive seasons, while averaging 70.8 targets, 47.2 receptions, 485.4 yards and 2.4 touchdowns per season. He failed to post a single top-15 fantasy season during the span. Clay is now 30 years old and will compete with Maxx Williams for top billing in the Arizona tight end room. There's not much upside here in a new-look offense that won't throw to the tight end much.

name: Evan Engram
weekly_outlook: A first-round pick back in 2017, Engram has missed six games due to injury but has produced at a high level when he's been healthy. In fact, he's ranked fourth and seventh, respectively, in fantasy points per game during his two seasons. Engram enters his third season positioned for an even larger role after New York traded Odell Beckham to Cleveland. Engram exploded during the four games Beckham missed last season, posting weekly fantasy finishes of 12th, first, fourth and third to finish off the 2018 season. Engram posted a top-10 fantasy week during 45 percent of his 2018 outings, which was sixth-best at the position. He ranked seventh with a 9.2 YPR and third with an 8.6 RAC. Engram is locked into a huge role in his third season and is a midrange TE1.

name: David Montgomery
weekly_outlook: The Bears selected Montgomery in the third round of April's draft to help replace Jordan Howard, whom they traded to the Eagles. Montgomery figures to immediately play a significant role along with change-of-pace back Tarik Cohen. He is one of the biggest backs in this class (5-foot-10, 222 pounds). His on-field profile is very similar to Kareem Hunt's, as he lacks some speed (4.63 40-yard dash) and explosiveness, but makes up for it with a combination of power, balance and especially elusiveness. The Iowa State product evaded a tackle once for every 5.1 touches last season (second best in the class) and is also a good receiver and blocker. Montgomery is a potential workhorse and, though he'll defer a lot of targets to Cohen this season, Montgomery could push for 200-plus carries. Consider him a fringe RB2.

name: Will Fuller V
weekly_outlook: Fuller has certainly flashed the upside that made him a first-round draft pick back in 2016, but he has yet to finish a season as a top-60 fantasy wide receiver. Durability has been the obvious issue, as Fuller has missed at least two games during each of his three seasons, including six in 2017 and nine in 2018. Last season, Fuller handled career-high 21 percent target share and sat 14th at the position in fantasy points prior to suffering a season-ending injury in Week 8. The downfield playmaker has scored 11 touchdowns in 17 games during the past two seasons. Fuller is still only 25 years old and has big upside if he can stay on the field, but with DeAndre Hopkins, Keke Coutee and now Kenny Stills in the mix, he may not be worth the cost for fantasy drafters. Consider him a flex option.

name: Chargers D/ST
weekly_outlook: The Chargers D/ST posted its worst fantasy finish in three seasons but finished 12th in 2018. The unit has ranked top-eight in points allowed each of the past two seasons but fell from sixth in both forced turnovers (27) and interceptions (18) in 2017 to 16th (20) and 15th (13), respectively, in 2018. Corey Liuget, Darius Philon and Jahleel Addae are notable offseason subtractions, but Thomas Davis and early-round picks Jerry Tillery and Nasir Adderley were huge additions at need spots. Additionally, edge rusher Joey Bosa will be healthy opposite Melvin Ingram this time around. Add that group to Casey Hayward, Derwin James (once back from IR) and Desmond King, and you have a strong unit on paper. Consider the Chargers' D/ST a top-10 unit.

name: Mohamed Sanu
weekly_outlook: Many think of Julio Jones and Calvin Ridley when discussing Falcons wide receivers, but it was actually Sanu who paced the unit in snaps (789) last season. Sanu worked ahead of Ridley most weeks and quietly tied him in targets (92). Sanu posted a 66/838/4 line and finished 31st in fantasy points (he was 29th in 2017). Sanu is still in his prime at age-29 and is a super reliable short-area target for Matt Ryan. Sanu has ranked Top 15 in catch rate and Bottom 15 in aDOT during each of the past four seasons. He posted a career-high 9.1 YPT in 2018. Touchdowns are the red flag here, as Sanu has never cleared five in a season. The veteran slot man figures to defer plenty of targets to second-year Ridley, but there are plenty to go around in this offense. Sanu remains a sneaky flex in deeper leagues.

name: Seahawks D/ST
weekly_outlook: The Seattle D/ST finished 14th in fantasy points last season, which marks its first finish worse than ninth since 2010. Seattle ranked 18th in interceptions (12), 24th in tackles for loss (82) and 25th in yards per play (5.92). The unit was 10th in forced turnovers (26) and 11th in points allowed (347), though a league-high 14 fumble recoveries will be hard to repeat. Earl Thomas, Frank Clark and Justin Coleman were big offseason losses, though Jadeveon Clowney and Ziggy Ansah will help offset those moves. This is a defense with good coaching but very shaky personnel in some areas, especially cornerback. Add and start the Seattle D/ST only when the unit is at home and the matchup is good. That will be the case in Week 1 against the Bengals.

name: Texans D/ST
weekly_outlook: The Houston D/ST bounced back last season following a disastrous and injury-plagued 2017 season. Houston ranked fourth in forced turnovers (29), 11th in sacks (43) and second in fantasy points (133) and scored four touchdowns. Houston allowed 316 points (fourth-fewest) after surrendering a league-high 436 points in 2017. Four of coach Bill O'Brien's past five and six of DC Romeo Crennel's past seven defenses have been better than average in touchdowns allowed. This unit is still solid at linebacker and at edge rusher, but the offseason losses of Jadeveon Clowney and in the secondary can't be overlooked. To make matters worse, a Week 1 trip to New Orleans means this D/ST is not a great draft selection.

name: Alexander Mattison
weekly_outlook: Looking to fill a need after the offseason departure of Latavius Murray, Minnesota selected Mattison with the No. 102 pick in April's draft. Mattison is a big, between-the-tackles back at 5-foot-11, 221 pounds, but also has good receiving and blocking chops. Mattison, who handled a whopping 302 carries at Boise State last season, lacks speed (4.67 YPC) and quickness, but has the size and skill set to settle in as a reliable backup. That's the role he'll play in 2019 as Dalvin Cook's handcuff.

name: Jalen Richard
weekly_outlook: After flashing on a grand total of 195 touches his first two NFL seasons, Richard finally earned an expanded role in Jon Gruden's first season at the helm. Richard was limited to a career-low 55 carries, but his 80 targets more than doubled his previous career high. He caught 85 percent of his targets (fourth-best) and finished top-eight at the position in yards per target (7.6) for the second season in a row. Although Oakland called pass on 81 percent of Richard's snaps, he averaged more than 4.7 YPC for the third consecutive season. Richard scored only one touchdown, his best weekly fantasy finish was 16th, and he's a candidate for a dip in targets after Oakland revamped at wide receiver. His role as a complement to Josh Jacobs is enough for flex value in deep PPR leagues.

name: Jets D/ST
weekly_outlook: The Jets finished 22nd in D/ST fantasy points last season, which was their fifth finish worse than 20th in the past six seasons. The Jets ranked near mid-pack in most categories. They ranked poorly in yards allowed (eighth-worst) and points allowed (fourth-worst) but were strong in blocks (second) and touchdowns (five). The defense includes a lot of talent, including Jamal Adams, Leonard Williams, Henry Anderson, Trumaine Johnson, C.J. Mosley and Quinnen Williams, though cornerback depth and edge rush are major concerns. This is a sleeper unit to keep in mind in deeper leagues.

name: Noah Fant
weekly_outlook: Denver selected Fant with the No. 20 pick in April's draft. Fant has a ways to go as a blocker and needs to cut down on drops, but he's a terrific receiver who will operate as an F/move tight end in the pros. Fant is 6-foot-4, 249 pounds and a terrific athlete with good speed and production near the end zone. He was tops at the position in the 40-yard-dash (4.50), vertical (39.5 inches), broad jump (127 inches), three cone (6.81) and 60-yard shuttle (11.49) at the combine. Fant figures to begin his career in a time-share with Jeff Heuerman, but could make some noise in fantasy as the season progresses. He's not a bad late flier in deeper leagues.

name: Taylor Gabriel
weekly_outlook: Gabriel signed with the Bears last season and played a larger role than most anticipated. Gabriel caught 67 passes (25th most at the position) for 688 yards and a pair of touchdowns. His 72 percent catch rate was 14th best among receivers and marks the third season in a row in which he's finished no lower than the 75th percentile in the category. The sure-handed Gabriel has dropped one of 194 targets during the past three seasons. Gabriel's small frame (5-foot-8, 167 pounds) has led to only 17 end zone targets and 10 touchdowns in six seasons. The 28-year-old figures to open 2019 as Chicago's No. 2 or 3 receiver, but he'll be hard-pressed to fend off youngsters Anthony Miller and Riley Ridley as the season progresses. Gabriel is underrated as a player, but has minimal fantasy upside.

name: Damien Harris
weekly_outlook: The Patriots selected Harris in the third round of April's draft. The Alabama product joins 2018 first-round pick Sony Michel, James White and Rex Burkhead on the New England depth chart. The 5-foot-10, 216-pound Harris actually out-snapped first-round pick Josh Jacobs last season, but wasn't quite as explosive or dynamic. Harris actually found himself averaging a full yard more prior to initial contact than Jacobs, but forced tackles at a below-average rate and underwhelmed after contact (3.0 YAC). Harris lacks top-end speed (4.57 40-yard dash), but is a powerful, downhill runner with exceptional ball security (zero fumbles last season). He's also a good pass-catcher and blocker, which supplies him with three-down upside in the pros. He may not get that opportunity anytime soon with Michel and White locked into offensive roles. Harris is worth no more than a late-round flier.

name: Ryan Griffin
weekly_outlook: Griffin has missed at least two games in three of the past four seasons and has never finished a season better than 24th in fantasy points. The 2013 sixth-round pick has managed 37 catches over the past two seasons and has never eclipsed two touchdowns in a single season. The 29-year-old will try to hold down the fort in New York during Chris Herndon's suspension, but has little fantasy appeal.

name: Jesse James
weekly_outlook: James signed with Detroit after spending the first four seasons of his career in Pittsburgh. James played a ton of snaps during his time in Pittsburgh (2,379 to be exact) but was asked to block on 50 percent of those plays, which allowed him only 42.75 targets per season. Despite his massive 6-foot-7, 261-pound frame, James never scored more than three touchdowns in a season. His best fantasy season was a 22nd-place finish in 2017. Especially with first-round pick T.J. Hockenson in the fold, James' primary job will be blocking in a run-first Detroit offense, which means he has almost no fantasy appeal.

name: Chris Moore
weekly_outlook: The Ravens have ranked no higher than 25th in three-plus wide receiver sets over the past five seasons. A majority of that came with Joe Flacco under center, though Baltimore ranked 26th (65%) in the category during Lamar Jackson's seven regular season starts last season. Moore, a 2016 fourth-round pick, may truly get an opportunity to break out this season, but Baltimore's run-heavy attack figures to cap the fantasy appeal of most of the team's pass catchers.

name: Drew Sample
weekly_outlook: The Bengals selected Sample in the second round of April's draft. Sample (6-foot-5, 255 pounds) is a good blocker and competent pass catcher who has drawn Jack Doyle comps. He has a good combination of speed, hands and ball skills, which were highlighted by him hauling in all but one of his 26 catchable targets last season, as well as a solid combine showing (including a 4.71 40-yard dash). Like most rookie tight ends, expect Sample to play a situational role as a rookie. He has little fantasy value with Tyler Eifert and C.J. Uzomah ahead of him on the depth chart.

name: David Johnson
weekly_outlook: Johnson's career has hit a snag since he dominated the fantasy scene in 2016, pacing all backs in snaps, touches, yardage, touchdowns and fantasy points. An injury cost him all but 43 snaps in 2017, and inefficient play in a weak offense limited him to only two top-10 fantasy weeks (24 backs had more) in 2018. Johnson's yards per carry plummeted to 3.64, his YAC to 1.44 (seventh-worst among running backs) and his catch rate to 66 percent (second-worst). On the plus side, Johnson ranked top-five at the position in snaps (714) and touches (308), which allowed him his third top-10 fantasy campaign in four seasons. The 27-year-old workhorse is expected to retain a hefty role in new coach Kliff Kingsbury's offense. An intriguing bounce-back candidate, Johnson is a mid-pack RB1.

name: Alvin Kamara
weekly_outlook: Following as efficient a season as you'll find for any running back (let alone a rookie) in 2017, Kamara's 2018 went about as expected: He regressed to the mean, but still played at a high level and was a terrific fantasy asset. The former third-round pick finished top-eight among backs in snaps (628), touches (275), scrimmage yards (1592), offensive touchdowns (18) and fantasy points (354). Kamara has yet to clear 200 carries in a season, but he has caught 81 passes in both of his NFL seasons and saw a significant uptick in work near the goal line last season (his 14.5 OTD ranked second in the league). Kamara's role won't change much with Latavius Murray added to replace Mark Ingram II. The 23-year-old back remains a solid RB1 option.

name: Davante Adams
weekly_outlook: Adams took his game to another level in 2018. In fact, before missing Week 17 because of an injury, Adams was the No. 1 scoring fantasy wide receiver. Incredibly, Adams ranked in the top 18 among wide receivers in all but one week last season (27th in Week 4) aside from the one week he missed. In addition to catching 13 touchdowns (second most), Adams ranked fourth at the position in routes (618), fourth in targets (164), fifth in receptions (111) and sixth in receiving yards (1,386). Adams has hauled in 35 touchdowns over the past three seasons, which trails only Antonio Brown for most in the league. Adams has done this damage despite missing at least one game three of the past four seasons. The 26-year-old soaked up a massive 30 percent target share last season and has little competition for targets again in 2019. He's a fine choice in the middle of the first round.

name: Sammy Watkins
weekly_outlook: Watkins hasn't posted a top 40 fantasy season since 2015, but injuries have been a big culprit. The 2014 first-round pick averaged a 21 percent target share (6.9 per game) during the 10 games he played in full last season. Believe it or not, he trailed Tyreek Hill (73) by only four targets during those weeks. Eight of the 10 games came during the regular season and Watkins was fantasy's No. 16 scoring wideout those weeks. Watkins posted a healthy 9.4 YPT despite a career-low 8.4 aDOT. Bizarrely, he was limited to one end zone target, which explains his three touchdowns. Watkins' durability is an obvious concern (he has missed at least three games during three of the past four seasons) but he plays a big role in arguably the league's best offense, which makes him a WR3 with WR2 upside.

name: Vikings D/ST
weekly_outlook: The Minnesota D/ST finished fifth in fantasy points last season, marking its fourth consecutive top-11 campaign. Minnesota has been especially good in points allowed (ninth or better each of the past four seasons) and yards allowed (fourth or better each of the past three seasons) but added 50 sacks (third) to its arsenal in 2018. The losses of Sheldon Richardson and Andrew Sendejo cannot be ignored, but a strong core led by Linval Joseph, Danielle Hunter and Harrison Smith remains intact. Minnesota sports a solid top-five D/ST unit.

name: Delanie Walker
weekly_outlook: Walker is back after his 2018 season was derailed by a broken ankle after only 38 snaps. One of the league's most underrated players of the past decade, Walker entered last season having posted three consecutive top-five fantasy campaigns and five straight top-12 finishes. Prior to 2018, Walker had appeared in at least 15 games in seven consecutive seasons and, from 2014-17, finished no lower than ninth at tight end in targets, receptions and receiving yards. Walker turns 35 years old this year but is again positioned for a large target share in Tennessee. He's a terrific mid- to late-round target with top-five upside.

name: Josh Gordon
weekly_outlook: Gordon was reinstated in August and will rejoin the Patriots this season. The 28-year-old wide receiver wasn't nearly as dominant last season as he was back at his peak in 2013, but was still very effective, ranking sixth among wide receivers in ypr (18.0), 10th in ypt (10.2) and fourth in RAC (6.7). Gordon was often utilized as a vertical threat (13.8 aDOT), which limited his volume a bit; during the nine full games he played, Gordon (63) was behind both Julian Edelman (83) and James White (70) in targets. Gordon ranked 24th in fantasy points during those nine weeks. He's back in the WR3 discussion, but his off-field troubles make him a risky early-round investment.

name: A.J. Green
weekly_outlook: Green has been one of the league's top wide receivers since entering the league in 2011, but he hasn't finished a season better than ninth in fantasy points since 2013. Durability has been a big culprit, as Green has missed at least three games during three of the past five seasons, including a total of 12 games over the past three seasons. He's also expected to miss around a month to begin 2019. When Green has been on the field, he has been effective, ranking no lower than 16th in fantasy points per game during each of his eight NFL seasons. Green, who is averaging 9.0 targets per game since the start of the 2017 season, turns 31 this season and figures to have a few good years left in the tank. He's a solid WR2 once back from injury.

name: Sterling Shepard
weekly_outlook: Shepard received a contract extension during the offseason and, with Odell Beckham Jr. gone, he will team up with Golden Tate to lead the Giants' wide receiver position in 2019. The 2016 second-round pick averaged 6.3 targets per game during the 12 games Beckham played and 8.0 per game during the four he missed last season. Shepard has finished 36th, 42nd and 30th in fantasy points during his three seasons. Though the 25-year-old is primarily a short-to-intermediate area target (9.3 career aDOT) who doesn't add much in the touchdown department (six during the past two seasons), Shepard figures to reach a career-high in targets this season and that would allow him to push for WR2 production.

name: Tyrell Williams
weekly_outlook: Williams heads to Oakland where - following the release of Antonio Brown - he'll take over as the team's No. 1 wideout. Williams was a full-time player, but primarily worked as a situational target throughout his four seasons with the Chargers. A Week 1 Keenan Allen injury forced Williams into No. 1 receiver duties back in 2016 and he delivered with a 69/1059/7 line and an 18th-place finish in fantasy points. That was, by far, Williams' most productive season and he's otherwise failed to eclipse five scores or post a fantasy finish better than 45th. Williams' resume suggests he won't be a high-volume target (he has been limited to a 13 percent target share each of the past two seasons), but his propensity for big plays (career 16.3 YPR) provides optimism that he can push for WR2 numbers.

name: Marquise Brown
weekly_outlook: The Ravens selected Brown with the No. 25 pick in April's draft. The former Oklahoma Sooner is extremely small (5-foot-9, 166 pounds), but he is superfast with the ability to get behind the defense and make plays with the ball in his hands. Drops (eight last season) and durability (he suffered a Lisfranc injury prior to the draft) are red flags, but Brown has the skill set of DeSean Jackson and John Brown, which allows him plenty of upside. The biggest concern here is that Brown's short-term fantasy value will be hindered by Baltimore's extremely run-heavy offense and Lamar Jackson's shaky accuracy. Brown is only worth a late flier in 2019 fantasy drafts because he has a good chance to lead the team in targets as a rookie.

name: Jared Cook
weekly_outlook: Cook signed with the Saints during the offseason after stints with the Titans, Rams, Packers and Raiders. After nine seasons in the league and no top-10 fantasy campaigns to show, Cook finally reached his potential with a breakout 2018 campaign. Cook hit career highs in targets (101), receptions (68), receiving yards (896) and touchdowns (six). He was fantasy's No. 5 scoring tight end. Cook's usage has been incredibly consistent, as he's averaged target shares between 16 and 18 percent each of the past seven seasons. If he keeps that streak alive in the Saints' high-scoring offense this season, Cook will no doubt post his second consecutive top-10 fantasy campaign. The 32-year-old is a solid TE1 target.

name: Drew Brees
weekly_outlook: Brees has remained one of the league's best passers in recent seasons, but his fantasy production has dropped off considerably since New Orleans improved defensively. Granted he sat out Week 17 last season, but Brees was limited to six top-10 fantasy weeks and finished outside the top seven for the season for the second year in a row. In 2018, Brees finished outside the top 10 in pass attempts, completions and yards for the first time since at least 2009. Brees, who has finished third or better in completion percentage nine of the past 10 seasons, has enough talent to post another top-10 season, but a more-balanced offense and fewer late-game deficits has capped his ceiling a bit.

name: Christian Kirk
weekly_outlook: Arizona selected Kirk in the second round of the 2018 draft and immediately slotted him in as a full-time player. Kirk was on the field for 85 percent of the team's pass plays and handled a generous 21 percent target share before landing on injured reserve with a broken foot. Kirk failed to post a single top-10 fantasy week, but was efficient, managing an 8.8 YPT and 5.3 RAC. Larry Fitzgerald is another year older, so the 22-year-old Kirk could very well take over as the team's No. 1 receiver this season, though he'll need to fend off rookies Andy Isabella and and KeeSean Johnson. Arizona's quarterback upgrade to Kyler Murray further helps Kirk's breakout chances. Consider him a borderline flex.

name: DeSean Jackson
weekly_outlook: Jackson spent his first six NFL seasons with the Eagles and now back with the team who drafted him following five combined seasons with Washington and Tampa Bay. The speedster is now 32 years old and has appeared in 16 games only twice in his 11-year career. Last season, Jackson was limited to 47 touches, but scored five touchdowns and posted an 18.9 YPR (highest) and 10.8 YPT (sixth highest). His 17.4 YPR and 10.0 YPT are tops in the NFL since he entered the league in 2008. Jackson is likely to miss a game or two and will serve as a situational deep threat behind Zach Ertz and Alshon Jeffery, but this is an offense that ranks fifth in passing attempts and third in passing touchdowns over the past two seasons. He'll see enough work to keep him in the flex discussion in non-PPR.

name: Rashaad Penny
weekly_outlook: Penny was a surprise selection in the first round of the 2018 draft, and his rookie season was derailed by injuries and the emergence of Chris Carson. Penny appeared in 14 games and was on the field for 17 percent of Seattle's offensive snaps. The good news is that he was effective, racking up 419 yards on 85 carries (4.9 YPC) and 75 yards on 12 targets (6.3 YPT). The 23-year-old back has the size, talent and skill set to emerge into a three-down back, but he remains behind Carson on the depth chart. Penny is a terrific handcuff but lacks stand-alone value in his current role.

name: Chris Thompson
weekly_outlook: Thompson has emerged as one of the league's better receiving backs in recent years, but injuries have derailed his chances for a full-on breakout. The 28-year-old back has missed exactly six games each of the past two seasons. Thompson's best season came in 2017, when he put up 804 scrimmage yards and six touchdowns on 103 touches in 10 games. Thompson has never cleared 68 carries in a season (though he has benefited from light boxes), but he's averaging an impressive 4.96 YPC in his career. Interestingly, he paced the position in YPR (13.1) and YPT (9.8) in 2017 but finished sixth-worst (6.4) and fifth-worst (4.9), respectively, last season. Thompson will continue to be limited to passing situations behind Adrian Peterson and Derrius Guice, which severely limits his fantasy upside. He's worth a look in deep PPR leagues.

name: Derrius Guice
weekly_outlook: Guice was the 59th overall pick in the 2018 draft, but a torn ACL in the preseason ended his rookie campaign before it even started. Guice is expected to be healthy for Week 1, but especially with Chris Thompson back, Adrian Peterson re-signed and Bryce Love drafted, it's hard to imagine the LSU product playing a full-time role early in the season. On the plus side, Guice is only 22 years old and has the size and ability to operate as a three-down back. He'll be a risky play early this season but has breakout potential once he's back to 100 percent.

name: Rex Burkhead
weekly_outlook: Burkhead has appeared in 23 games across two seasons with the Patriots, handling roughly one quarter of the carries and just under 10 percent of the targets during both seasons. Last season's 3.3 YPC was both the worst of his career and fourth-worst at the position, but note that he has finished second and first, respectively, in average box defenders each of the past two seasons. The 29-year-old is a competent rusher and effective receiver with a defined role in one of the league's best offenses. He has little standalone value, and that's doubtful to change with James White, Sony Michel and Damien Harris all on the roster.

name: Dante Pettis
weekly_outlook: Pettis was a somewhat-surprising second-round draft pick last season, but made some noise with a solid rookie campaign. Albeit a small sample, Pettis averaged 17.3 YPR and 10.6 YPT while hauling in 27 of 44 targets for 467 yards and five touchdowns. He ran at least 80 percent of the pass routes in four games stretching from Week 12-15 and was fantasy's No. 8 wideout during the span. Especially with Jimmy Garoppolo back under center, the 23-year-old Pettis is positioned for a step forward in his second season. He's a flex option with upside.

name: Stephen Gostkowski
weekly_outlook: Gostkowski has finished as a top-three kicker six of the past eight seasons, but his two worst finishes in that span (eighth in 2016 and ninth in 2018) have come in the past three seasons. His 50 extra-point attempts last season were fourth most in the league. His efficiency was lacking last season, as he missed five of 32 field goal attempts, despite an average distance of 36.2 yards (second lowest). Gostkowski is now 35 years old, but just signed a contract extension to remain the kicker for one of the league's top offenses. He's a solid starting option.

name: Will Dissly
weekly_outlook: Dissly took the fantasy landscape by storm last season, as the relatively unheralded rookie tight end exploded for a 6-147-2 line and the third-most fantasy points at the position through Week 2. Dissly predictably came back to earth a bit in Week 3 before suffering a season-ending knee injury in Week 4. The 2018 fourth-round pick was targeted 13 times through three weeks (third most on the team), though he ran a route on only 53 percent of the team's pass plays. Dissly figures to take on a larger role in his second season, which makes him a fine late flier, but Seattle's run-heavy offense will limit his upside.

name: Chris Herndon
weekly_outlook: The Jets selected Herndon in the fourth round of the 2018 draft and quickly put him in position for a big role. Herndon was on the field for 63 percent of New York's snaps, including 50 percent of pass plays. Following a slow start to the season, Herndon was fantasy's No. 9 tight end from Week 6 on. His 10.3 aDOT was fifth-highest at the position and helped him to a strong 9.0 YPT (10th). Herndon's 502 receiving yards rank 11th, his catch rate 10th, his YPT fifth and his aDOT third among rookie tight ends over the past 12 seasons. Herndon is in prime position for a second-year breakout, but will miss Weeks 1-4 due to suspension.

name: Michael Badgley
weekly_outlook: Badgley went undrafted last offseason, but signed on with the Chargers to replace Caleb Sturgis during the 2018 regular season. The Miami product proved to be a big upgrade. Badgley was the Chargers' kicker for 10 games and ranked 10th in fantasy points during those weeks. He attempted only 16 field goals, but converted 15 (a single-season franchise-record 93.8 percent) and made 27 of 28 extra points. Badgley also connected on five of six attempts in the playoffs. The 23-year-old has brought some much-needed stability to the Chargers' kicking game and is a fringe starting option.

name: Dion Lewis
weekly_outlook: The Titans signed Lewis last offseason and gave him a legitimate opportunity to lead a backfield that included Derrick Henry. It didn't pan out. After averaging 5.0 YPC and a league-best 2.6 YAC in 2017, Lewis averaged 3.3 YPC and 2.0 YAC in 2018. He was more productive as a receiver, catching 59 passes (10th-most among backs) and pacing the position in catch rate (87 percent) for the second consecutive season. Lewis scored two touchdowns, and all four of his top-25 fantasy weeks came prior to Week 11. Following Henry's late-season breakout, Lewis is no more than a change-of-pace back and passing-down specialist. That gives the 28-year-old some deep-league appeal, but he isn't a viable starting option.

name: John Ross III
weekly_outlook: Ross made his name with a record 4.22-second 40-yard dash at the 2017 NFL combine, but his career is off to a rough start. Ross battled through injuries and fumbled on his only touch as a rookie before posting a bizarre 21/210/7 line on 58 targets in 2018. The 2017 ninth overall pick caught 36 percent of his targets and averaged 3.6 YPT, both of which were worst at the position. Granted, a league-high 36 percent of balls thrown his way were off target, but Ross averaged only 10.0 YPR despite a 13.9 aDOT (15th highest). He scored seven touchdowns, but his 4.8 OTD suggests that's unsustainable. Durability is a major concern for the 23-year-old, as he already has missed 16 games with various injuries. He could still turn the corner, but he's no more than a dynasty stash.

name: Paul Richardson Jr.
weekly_outlook: Richardson signed a five-year, $40 million contract with Washington last offseason following a 2017 season in Seattle in which he set career-highs in targets (80), receptions (44), yardage (703) and touchdowns (six) last year. His first year in Washington didn't go well, as he hurt his shoulder in Week 1 and then struggled to a 20/262/2 line in seven games before landing on injured reserve. The 2014 second-round pick has overcome a lot, having torn his ACL in both 2012 and during the 2014 playoffs before suffering a season-ending hamstring injury in 2015. Richardson is now healthy, still in his prime at age-27 and very well could lead Washington in targets. He's a fine late-round post-hype target.

name: Deebo Samuel
weekly_outlook: The 49ers spent the No. 36 overall pick in April's draft on Samuel, adding him to a wide receiver room that is highlighted by Dante Pettis and Marquise Goodwin. Samuel is one of the most versatile weapons among this year's rookies. The South Carolina product can play inside and out and contributes as a receiver, rusher and kick returner. He has sufficient size (5-foot-11, 214 pounds) with strong hands, route-running ability and is terrific after the catch (9.7 RAC last season). Durability is a concern, as he has struggled with hamstring injuries during his career. Samuel figures to at least play in three-wide sets as a rookie and could push for more on what is a wide-open depth chart. He's worth a late-round flier.

name: Ito Smith
weekly_outlook: Smith was selected in the fourth round of last year's draft and spent most of his rookie season working in a situational role behind Tevin Coleman. Smith wasn't particularly impressive, managing only 315 yards and four scores on 90 carries (3.5 YPC, 1.4 YAC) and 27 receptions for 152 yards on 32 targets. His 5.6 YPR was dead last at running back. Smith is positioned for a similar role in 2019, this time as a change-of-pace back behind Devonta Freeman. Smith has minimal standalone value, but is Freeman's likely handcuff in an offense that is rarely short on points.

name: Jordan Reed
weekly_outlook: At times, Reed has been one of the league's most-dominant tight ends. Unfortunately, he simply can't stay on the field. The 2013 third-round pick has never played more than 14 games in a regular season and has missed 31 games in six seasons. Reed handled a hefty 23 percent target share (6.9 per game) during the 12 full games he played last season. That aligns exactly with his usage during the 2015-16 seasons and is just above where he was in five full games in 2017 (21 percent). Despite only scoring two touchdowns in Washington's mess of an offense, Reed was fantasy's No. 8 scoring tight end before going down with an injury in Week 14 last season. He'll again be ticketed for a huge role in 2019, though his durability remains a massive concern.

name: N'Keal Harry
weekly_outlook: The Patriots selected Harry with the final pick of the first round of April's draft. Harry is 6-foot-2, 228 pounds and is a strong, physical downfield weapon and good blocker. The Arizona State product is terrific with the ball in his hands and his size makes him a valuable resource near the goal line. Harry's speed (4.53 40-yard dash) and athletic limitations have led to struggles with separation, so he might be best suited for a big slot role in the pros. That makes him a fit in a Patriots offense that moves its receivers around quite often. Harry will begin his pro career on IR and will be hard-pressed to land consistent target volume behind Julian Edelman, Josh Gordon and perhaps Demaryius Thomas once he returns late in the season. He's only worth rostering in dynasty leagues.

name: Vernon Davis
weekly_outlook: Davis is now 35 years old but continues to make an impact as a situational seam stretcher. Davis has ranked Top 10 in aDOT each of the past 10 seasons and has finished top 10 in both YPT and YPR each of the past three seasons.
