He's been limited to no more than 68 targets and hasn't cleared three touchdowns in a season since 2013, however, which also marks the season of his last top-15 fantasy campaign. Davis is Jordan Reed's handcuff but would only be a TE2 if Reed were to miss time.

name: Marcus Mariota
weekly_outlook: Mariota is entering his fifth NFL season, but has yet to play a full 16-game regular season and has never finished a campaign better than 12th in fantasy points. He's a tough read, as he shines in some areas (no worse than the 64th percentile in adjusted completion rate and better than average in yards per attempt in each of his four seasons) and struggles in others (24 TDs, 23 INTs over the past two seasons). Despite missing four games during the span, Mariota has ranked no lower than eighth in carries and rushing yards at the position each of the past three seasons. He lacks upside in Tennessee's run-heavy offense and is best viewed as a QB3.

name: Lamar Miller
weekly_outlook: Miller tore his ACL and is out for the 2019 season. Miller finished 23rd among running backs in fantasy points in 2018, which marks his worst finish since 2013. Miller handled 56 percent of Houston's carries and 9 percent of the targets during 14 regular-games last season, but he managed only one top-10 fantasy week. His rushing efficiency (4.6 YPC, 2.0 YAC) was solid, but he was limited to 35 targets (his fewest since 2013) and averaged a career-low and position-worst 4.7 yards per target. The 28-year-old is not a lock to be back with Houston in 2020.

name: Devin Funchess
weekly_outlook: Funchess broke out in 2017, plummeted to near-irrelevance in 2018 and now has a terrific bounce back opportunity after signing a one-year deal with the Colts. The 2015 second-round pick first stepped into a full-time role in 2017 and exploded for a 63/840/8 line and a 22nd-place fantasy campaign. The towering 6-foot-4, 225-pound receiver played a similar role early in 2018, but inefficient play and a change in scheme eventually led to a demotion. Funchess now has a decent opportunity to rebound, as the depth chart is wide open behind T.Y. Hilton and he figures to be busy near the goal line (ranks 23rd with 32 career end zone targets). The 25-year-old has some sleeper appeal, but Andrew Luck's retirement hurts his upside.

name: Ty Montgomery
weekly_outlook: Montgomery signed with the Jets and is expected to work as a passing-down complement to Le'Veon Bell this season. A third-round pick in 2015, Montgomery has bounced between wide receiver and running during stints with the Packers and Ravens over the past four seasons. Though he is averaging a healthy 4.7 YPC in his career, Montgomery has never cleared 102 carries in a season. That's unlikely to change in 2019, even if Bell misses time with an injury. The versatile Montgomery figures to soak up only a handful of touches most weeks, though Jets coach Adam Gase found creative paths to big plays for Albert Wilson and Jakeem Grant in Miami, and Montgomery figures to be ticketed for some of those opportunities. Montgomery has minimal fantasy value barring a Bell injury.

name: Marquise Goodwin
weekly_outlook: Goodwin was one of fantasy's most popular sleepers last season, but injuries derailed his run at his first top-30 fantasy campaign. He patched together only six games in which he was on the field for at least two-thirds of the 49ers' offensive snaps. He posted a 15/314/3 line and ranked 30th in fantasy points during those weeks. One of the league's fastest players, the track star ranked in the top 10 in aDOT in both 2016 and 2017. His 17.2 YPR in 2017 was fourth highest in the league. Goodwin has appeared in 16 games once and at least 13 games twice in his six-year NFL career. Especially with Jimmy Garoppolo healthy, the 28-year-old Goodwin is a fine late-round, post-hype sleeper, but his path to snaps will be tougher with rookies Deebo Samuel and Jalen Hurd added to the fold.

name: Willie Snead IV
weekly_outlook: Baltimore attacked wide receiver early in April's draft, but Snead still came out as the team's primary slot receiver. The 26-year-old ranked 32nd in the league with 95 targets last season, but his short-area role (8.6 aDOT) allowed only 651 yards (50th). He managed only one touchdown thanks to one end zone target and a 1.9 OTD. Snead's 1.1 touchdown rate was worst at the position and he has yet to eclipse four touchdowns in a single season in his career. Snead could soak up a decent target share in Baltimore this season, but the combination of the Ravens' extremely run-heavy offense, Lamar Jackson's inaccuracies and Snead's minimal role near the goal line leaves him with little fantasy appeal. He has barely worth a look in deep PPR leagues.

name: C.J. Anderson
weekly_outlook: Anderson's 2018 was a tale of two stories. Anderson signed with Carolina during the offseason and was limited to 128 yards on 25 touches across nine games as Christian McCaffrey's backup. He signed with the Rams later in the year and went on to explode for 522 yards and four scores on 96 touches in only five games (including the playoffs). With Todd Gurley sidelined, Anderson paced all backs in fantasy points during Weeks 16-17. Anderson, who has ranked in the upper two-thirds at the position in YAC during four of his five NFL seasons, now joins the Lions, where he'll work alongside versatile Kerryon Johnson and rookie PJ Johnson. LeGarrette Blount (no longer with the Lions) averaged 8.1 carries per game in this role last season, and we should anticipate something similar for Anderson. The 28-year-old has some handcuff appeal in Detroit's run-first offense.

name: Jerick McKinnon
weekly_outlook: McKinnon signed a pricy contract with San Francisco last offseason but will now miss both the 2018 and 2019 seasons following a torn ACL. The 5-foot-9, 212-pound McKinnon has yet to exceed 159 carries in a season and averaged 3.59 YPC (worst), including 1.50 after contact (second-worst) on 309 carries in the 2016 and 2017 seasons. McKinnon's receiving volume has been terrific, but his efficiency has been weak (7.2 YPR). Those numbers are alarming, and missing two full seasons due to injury is an even larger problem. McKinnon barely has dynasty value at this point.

name: Parris Campbell
weekly_outlook: The Colts selected Campbell in the second round of April's draft. It's a solid landing spot, as the Colts' wide receiver depth chart is wide open behind T.Y. Hilton. Campbell was used extremely close to the line of scrimmage last season, posting a prospect-low 4.6 average depth of target and prospect-high 83 percent catch rate on 109 targets. Campbell, who checks in at 6-foot, 205 pounds, is extremely fast and athletic (receiver-best 4.31 40-yard dash and 4.03 short shuttle at the combine). The Ohio State product primarily worked from the slot (91 percent) last season and that's where he figures to align in Indianapolis, while also contributing as a rusher and kick returner (think Randall Cobb). Campbell is a fine late flier, but Andrew Luck's retirement hurts his short-term appeal.

name: Tre'Quan Smith
weekly_outlook: Smith racked up 42 targets in 15 regular-season games while operating as a reserve for most of his rookie campaign. The third-round pick flashed his upside during a 48-7 whooping of the Eagles in which he posted a 10/157/1 line on 13 targets. He also scored on two of three receptions against Washington earlier in the season. Smith's combination of size (6-foot-2, 210 pounds) and downfield playmaking ability makes him an intriguing breakout candidate in the Saints' high-scoring and efficient offense, but the 23-year-old will need to beat out the likes of Ted Ginn Jr. and Keith Kirkwood for a full-time role opposite Michael Thomas. He's a terrific post-hype target in the late rounds.

name: Zay Jones
weekly_outlook: A second-round pick in 2017, Jones' NFL career started poorly with a 27/316/2 line on 68 rookie-season targets. He ranked dead last in both catch rate (40 percent) and YPT (4.6). Granted, the bar was low, but he did take a step forward in 2018, posting a 56/652/7 line on 100 targets. His 56 percent catch rate and 6.5 YPT again ranked near the bottom of the league and his 2.5 RAC (fourth worst) was actually down from 2.7 in 2017. Jones' heavy volume (27th in targets) and boost in scoring (13th in touchdowns) allowed him a 35th-place finish in fantasy points, but the efficiency woes can't be ignored. That's especially the case with inaccurate Josh Allen under center and with Cole Beasley and John Brown added to the mix. Jones no longer has a clear path to a starting role and is worth only a flier in very deep leagues.

name: Nick Foles
weekly_outlook: Foles signed on with the Jaguars after a roller-coaster career that has fallen as low as him nearly retiring several years ago to as high as winning the Super Bowl LII MVP. Though Foles has flashed at times, he's never played more than 13 games in a single regular season and has finished one season better than 29th in fantasy points. Incredibly, Foles has registered exactly two weekly fantasy finishes better than 16th over the past three seasons. In seven games last season (including the playoffs), he tossed eight interceptions and fumbled four times. His 72 percent completion percentage was second best in the league, though his 6.8 aDOT was second lowest. Foles offers nothing with his legs, his supporting cast won't be nearly as strong in Jacksonville and the Jaguars operate a run-first offense. He shouldn't be drafted.

name: Mike Davis
weekly_outlook: Davis joins the Bears after bouncing around the league for the first four seasons of his career. Davis made some noise during a career-best season in Seattle in 2018. He notched a career-high 728 yards and five scores on 146 touches. Though his efficiency has progressively improved, Davis is averaging an ugly 3.6 YPC (1.6 YAC) and 5.4 YPT in his career. The 26-year-old will have some non-PPR value only if he surprisingly beats out rookie David Montgomery for early-down and goal-line duties. Davis is best viewed as a handcuff with limited upside.

name: Dwayne Haskins
weekly_outlook: The Redskins selected Haskins with the No. 15 overall pick in April's draft. The 6-foot-3, 231-pound pocket passer has a huge arm and throws an accurate ball, especially in the short area. Haskins posted a low-end 7.9 aDOT at Ohio State last season, though he made his passes count with a strong 70 percent completion rate and 50 touchdowns to only eight interceptions. Haskins offers very little as a rusher (108 rushing yards in 14 career starts, 5.04 40-yard dash), which means he will need to do his heavy lifting in fantasy with his arm. History suggests pocket quarterbacks are an extreme long shot for rookie-season fantasy relevance and Haskins will cede early-season starts to Case Keenum. He shouldn't be drafted in season-long leagues.

name: T.J. Yeldon
weekly_outlook: Yeldon signed with the Bills after not quite panning out in Jacksonville after the team selected him in the second round of the 2015 draft. With Leonard Fournette injured most of the season, Yeldon posted a career-best 22nd-place finish in fantasy points last season. He played a limited role as a rusher (104 carries), but finished top 12 in targets (76), receptions (55) and receiving yards (477), all of which were career-high marks. Yeldon has yet to hold up for a full 16-game season and has averaged a weak 4.0 YPC and 5.8 YPT in four NFL seasons. He's still in his prime at age 25, but will have a hard time finding touches behind Frank Gore and Devin Singletary.

name: Geoff Swaim
weekly_outlook: Swaim joins the Jaguars after pacing the Jason Witten-less Cowboys' tight end room in snaps (491) and targets (30), despite missing seven games last season. Despite playing a full-time role during the nine weeks he was active, Swaim was limited to a 26-242-1 line on 30 targets and sat 17th in fantasy points. The 2015 seventh-round pick entered the season with 11 career targets. He'll primarily be asked to block for Leonard Fournette in Jacksonville and has little fantasy value.

name: Eli Manning
weekly_outlook: Manning finished 2018 as the No. 17 scoring quarterback, which marked his first top 20 since 2015. Incredibly, the 38-year-old has posted one season better than 10th over the past 13 seasons. Manning has devolved into a conservative passer as he's ranked bottom 10 in aDOT each of the past two seasons. He isn't particularly efficient and offers very little with his legs with 37 rushing yards on 48 carries over the past three seasons. The Giants improved their offensive line, but swapped out Odell Beckham Jr. for Golden Tate during the offseason, which suggests New York is likely ticketed for a low-scoring, run-first offense heavy on short-area passing. Manning, who figures to defer some late-season starts to Daniel Jones, shouldn't be drafted in most formats.

name: J.J. Arcega-Whiteside
weekly_outlook: The Eagles selected Arcega-Whiteside in the second round of April's draft. He joins a deep wide receiver group that also includes Alshon Jeffery, DeSean Jackson and Nelson Agholor. Arcega-Whiteside is a big (6-foot-2, 225 pounds), strong weapon who thrives on contested catches and jump balls, especially near the goal line (only two players eclipsed his 14 touchdown catches last season). The Stanford product lacks top-end speed and isn't particularly dynamic with the ball in his hands (4.1 RAC last season), but he makes up for it with tremendous ball skills and good hands (he dropped one of 75 catchable passes in 2018). With the aforementioned trio, as well as Zach Ertz and Dallas Goedert in the mix for targets, Arcega-Whiteside will need an injury or two to enter the fantasy landscape in 2019. This is a good landing spot for his dynasty value, however.

name: Josh Rosen
weekly_outlook: The 10th-overall selection in the 2018 draft, Rosen started his rookie season on the bench, but was thrown to the wolves during a Week 3 loss to Chicago. Rosen went on to throw 11 touchdowns and 14 interceptions in 14 games. Granted his supporting cast was weak, but Rosen completed only 55 percent of his passes (second worst) and averaged 5.8 yards per attempt (third worst). He managed only two weekly fantasy finishes inside the top 20 and none were better than 14th. Rosen was infamously traded to Miami during the draft and will back up Ryan Fitzpatrick to open the 2019 season. Rosen figures to make a lot of starts this season, but won't be worth adding to your roster until he shows he's a capable NFL starter. He's worth holding only in dynasty.

name: Marqise Lee
weekly_outlook: Lee missed the entire 2018 season with a torn ACL and he's not expected to be back to full speed until August. Though the expectation is he'll return for Week 1, it's hard to invest much in a player who will miss so much of the offseason, not to mention one who has yet to finish a season better than 40th in fantasy points. Lee finished top 35 among wideouts in targets in both 2016 and 2017, but had more drops (12) than touchdowns (six) during the span. In fact, Lee has registered a grand total of eight touchdown receptions in 53 NFL games. The 27-year-old is back near full health, but is no longer locked into every-down duties. He has a low ceiling in the Jaguars' run-first offense and is only worth a look in deep leagues.

name: Josh Oliver
weekly_outlook: The Jaguars selected Oliver in the third round of April's draft. Oliver was busy at San Jose State last season, playing 780 snaps and handling 103 targets, the latter of which was most in this rookie class.  Oliver struggled a bit with efficiency, including eight drops, and isn't particularly quick (4.47 short shuttle). Oliver has a decent-sized frame (6-foot-5, 249 pounds) and could develop into a two-way tight end in the pros. In the short term, expect him share tight ends duties with veterans Geoff Swaim and James O'Shaughnessy. He doesn't have much 2019 fantasy value.

name: Robert Foster
weekly_outlook: Foster signed with the Bills as an undrafted free agent last offseason and ended up working his way into an every-down role for Buffalo's final four games. He posted a 19/285/2 line and was fantasy's No. 18 wide receiver on 25 targets during the span. Foster's rookie-season rate stats were off the charts, as he posted a 21.3 aDOT, 20.1 YPR and 11.9 YPT. Foster is entering his second NFL season, though he's already 25 years old. With John Brown and Cole Beasley added to a room that also includes Zay Jones, Foster is now fourth on the depth chart. It's not an ideal situation in Buffalo's run-heavy offense, but Foster can't be completely ignored after an explosive finish to his rookie season. Keep him stashed in dynasty.

name: Quincy Enunwa
weekly_outlook: Enunwa returns to the Jets after a roller-coaster ride of production in recent seasons. Enunwa broke out with a 58/857/4 line in 2016 (his third NFL season) before missing all of 2017 with a neck injury. He seemed en route to a bounce-back campaign last season, registering eight-plus targets in each of his first four games, but was limited to 4.6 targets per game while battling injuries the rest of the season. Enunwa is now 27 years old, has played more than 12 games in a season once and has finished one season better than 84th in fantasy points. His outlook is helped by new coach Adam Gase (Dolphins WRs ranked 10th in fantasy points during his three seasons as head coach), but the ceiling here is low in a suddenly-crowded offense. He's barely worth draft-day consideration.

name: Theo Riddick
weekly_outlook: Riddick failed to score a touchdown and finished 43rd among running backs in fantasy points last season. That's notable because it was the first time the standout receiving back failed to score at least three touchdowns since 2013 and the first time he failed to finish 26th or better in fantasy since 2014. Although his 5.2 YPT was a career worst, Riddick caught 61 passes last season, which was ninth-most at the position and the second-highest total of his career. The past four seasons, Riddick ranks second at the position in targets (309), first in receptions (247), third in receiving yards (1896) and fifth in touchdown catches (10). The 28-year-old back is on a new roster, but he figures to remain busy in passing situations, which gives him some value in deep PPR leagues.

name: Hakeem Butler
weekly_outlook: The Cardinals drafted Butler in the fourth round of April's draft. The former Iowa State star is a massive 6-foot-5, 227 pounds with huge hands (10.8 inches) and an 83.9-inch wingspan, the latter of which was biggest among combine wide receivers. He has a good combination of speed (4.48 40-yard dash) and strength (18 bench reps), which helped him average 22.0 yards per reception on 60 catches last season. Butler lacks some short-area quickness and his biggest red flag is drops (he paced this year's rookie crop with 12 last season). He has a high ceiling, but is out for the 2019 season and best viewed as a dynasty stash.

name: Jalen Hurd
weekly_outlook: The 49ers drafted Hurd early in the third round of April's draft. Hurd is one of the biggest receivers in this class at 6-foot-5, 226 pounds. Despite his massive frame, Hurd was actually a running back who racked up 589 carries in three seasons at Tennessee before converting to slot receiver for one season at Baylor (48 carries, 107 targets in 2018). Hurd is obviously a very raw receiver, but his combination of versatility, athleticism and strength makes him an intriguing project. It's possible he quickly works his way up a wide-open 49ers depth chart, but Hurd is likely going to be a depth receiver as a rookie. Feel free to target him late in deeper leagues.

name: Drew Lock
weekly_outlook: Broncos GM John Elway likes tall, strong-armed pocket quarterbacks, so it was no surprise he selected Lock with the No. 42 pick in April's draft. Lock has an ideal frame (6-foot-4, 228 pounds), a very good arm, throws a good deep ball and offers some mobility (4.69 40-yard dash, 4.12 short shuttle). On the other hand, accuracy and struggles against pressure are concern areas. The Missouri product completed only 63 percent of his passes in 2018, which was actually the best of his career and required a massive drop in aDOT (8.5). Lock figures to make a few starts down the stretch this season, but he'll start out on IR. His only fantasy value is in dynasty.

name: Josh Doctson
weekly_outlook: Doctson, a 2016 first-round pick, missed all but 30 snaps of his rookie season (Achilles injury) and has posted lines of 35/502/6 and 44/532/2 on 76 targets during each of the past two seasons. Doctson appeared to be developing into a force near the goal line in 2017 when he handled 17 end zone targets (sixth most), but he saw only six in 2018. He has caught 52 percent of his career targets and is averaging a weak 7.0 YPT. Doctson is now 26 years old and is well off the fantasy radar after being cut by Washington.

name: Tyler Kroft
weekly_outlook: Kroft signed with the Bills after spending his first four NFL seasons in Cincinnati. The 2013 third-round pick posted a 42-404-7 line in relief of Tyler Eifert in 2017 but fell behind C.J. Uzomah last season and then was lost for the season with a broken foot. Kroft could snag the occasional touchdown, but he'll spend a lot of time blocking and is a poor bet for consistent fantasy production in Buffalo's run-heavy offense. He's not worth a draft pick.

name: Jace Sternberger
weekly_outlook: The Packers selected Sternberger in the third round of April's draft. The Texas A&M product is the presumed successor to 32-year-old Jimmy Graham, whose play slipped in 2018. Sternberger is fresh off a highly productive season, in which he paced all incoming tight ends with 10 touchdowns and caught 48 of 51 catchable targets. Sternberger is an athletic 6-foot-4, 251 pounds, a good route-runner with sure hands and he sports good post-catch and big-play ability. His frame raises questions about his potential blocking contributions in the pros, but he has plenty of experience in the area. Sternberger won't be a fantasy asset in 2019 as long as Graham is healthy, but could emerge as Green Bay's starter as soon as 2020.

name: C.J. Uzomah
weekly_outlook: Uzomah returns to Cincinnati after posting career-high marks in targets (64), receptions (43), receiving yards (439) and touchdowns (three) last season. Only seven tight ends played more snaps. Despite the step forward in 2018, Uzomah is expected to resume backup duties behind Tyler Eifert this season. Uzomah was out-targeted 15-to-7 by Eifert during the three games the two played together in full last season. Of course, Eifert has missed at least eight games four of the past five seasons, so Uzomah could sneak back into TE2 territory if Eifert goes down again. That's not enough to make him worth a draft pick.

name: Travis Benjamin
weekly_outlook: The Chargers increased their usage of three-plus wide receiver sets from 71% in 2017 (Anthony Lynn's first season as head coach) to 78% last season. The change was predictable with Hunter Henry out and with Mike Williams in his second season. Of course, with Henry back and Tyrell Williams gone, it's possible the number regresses in 2019. Benjamin is a noteworthy deep sleeper, but keep in mind that the 29 year old has one Top 45 fantasy campaign to his name and that was back in 2015.

name: Riley Ridley
weekly_outlook: Ridley was selected by the Bears in the fourth round of April's draft. Calvin's brother is 6-foot-1, 199 pounds and profiles as a physical possession receiver. Ridley is a quality route runner with reliable hands and was productive near the goal line at Georgia. The former Bulldog lacks top-end speed (4.58 40-yard dash) and post-catch production (ugly 3.4 RAC last season), but he should make his name in the short-to-intermediate area, while adding value as a run blocker. He does not have a clear path to snaps in 2019 with Allen Robinson, Taylor Gabriel, Anthony Miller and perhaps Cordarrelle Patterson higher on the depth chart. Ridley is only worth a look in dynasty.

name: Corey Clement
weekly_outlook: Clement was a popular 2018 fantasy sleeper but ended up resuming his role as a complementary player and saw his efficiency take a nosedive after a solid rookie season. Clement registered 444 yards and six touchdowns on 84 touches in 2017 before posting 451 yards and two scores on 90 touches in 2018 (10 games). Clement will have a hard time finding touches behind Jordan Howard, Darren Sproles and Miles Sanders. He has little fantasy appeal.

name: Isaiah Crowell
weekly_outlook: Crowell signed with the Raiders, but tore his ACL and is out for the 2019 season. Despite his release from the Jets early in the offseason, Crowell's efficiency was pretty solid in 2018. He averaged 4.8 YPC (second-highest of his career), including a career-best 2.1 YAC. Crowell has rushed for 3,803 yards since entering the league in 2014, which ranks ninth in the league. Crowell hasn't been quite as effective as a receiver, having failed to clear 200 receiving yards in four of his five seasons. Crowell has managed only one top-30 fantasy season in his career and figures to settle in as a committee back once he returns to health in 2020.

name: Equanimeous St. Brown
weekly_outlook: St. Brown was the third of three wide receivers selected by the Packers in the mid-to-late rounds of the 2018 draft. Though he did enough to overtake fourth-rounder J'Mon Moore on the depth chart, St. Brown was limited to 238 routes and 35 targets in 12 regular-season games. He posted a 21/328/0 receiving line and his best weekly fantasy finish was 26th. The 6-foot-5 receiver is out for the 2019 season.

name: Jake Butt
weekly_outlook: Butt is set to enter his third NFL season but has appeared in only three games thus far. Butt tore his ACL during the 2016 Orange Bowl and missed his entire rookie season after Denver selected him in the fifth round of the 2017 draft. Last season, he was targeted 12 times in three games before tearing his ACL at practice. The Michigan product is a solid pass-catcher with good hands, but he's not very fast or athletic. Butt was placed on IR again this season and is well off the fantasy radar.

name: Kelvin Harmon
weekly_outlook: Harmon surprisingly fell to the sixth round of April's draft, which is where he was selected by the Redskins. Harmon is a big (6-foot-2, 221 pounds), physical perimeter receiver with good hands, ball skills and blocking ability. The N.C. State product is not particularly speedy (4.64 40-yard dash) or quick and was dreadful after the catch last season, posting a prospect-worst 3.1 RAC. Of course, he still caught 81 passes while working as both a vertical threat and reliable possession target. Harmon has some upside despite his plummet on draft weekend, and Washington's shaky depth chart provides him plenty of opportunity for rookie-season playing time. Keep him on your watch list.

name: Chad Beebe
weekly_outlook: The Vikings have ranked right around league average in three-plus wide sets during each of Mike Zimmer's five seasons as the team's head coach. That includes 13th (79%) last season. Beebe, who went undrafted last year, made a brief appearance as a rookie, catching all four of his targets for 39 yards. The 25-year-old slot receiver has an opportunity to earn a significant role between Stefon Diggs and Adam Thielen. Minnesota's run-first offense figures to cap Beebe's upside, but there's some fantasy appeal in deep PPR formats.

name: Kenneth Dixon
weekly_outlook: Injuries and suspensions have marred Dixon's career since he was selected in the fourth round of the 2016 draft. Dixon was limited to six games in 2018 but got his career back on track a bit, racking up 333 yards and a pair of touchdowns on 60 rushes. Granted, the sample is small, but Dixon's 5.55 YPC was third-best, his 3.47 YAC topped the position and he paced all backs in Pro Football Focus' Elusive Rating. With a 2.22 YAC, Dixon ranked sixth in the category on 88 carries as a rookie. Dixon has been effective and is only 25 years old, but is on injured reserve and barely worth a dynasty roster spot.

name: Jeff Heuerman
weekly_outlook: Heuerman made some noise with a random 10-catch game in Week 9 last season, but otherwise failed to post a weekly fantasy finish better than 17th. The 2015 third-round pick has yet to appear in more than 14 games in a regular season and struggled badly with efficiency in a role as a short-area target last season. The 26-year-old is a long shot for fantasy value after Denver drafted Noah Fant in the first round of April's draft.

name: Kahale Warring
weekly_outlook: Houston selected Warring in the third round of April's draft. This after the team drafted tight ends Jordan Akins and Jordan Thomas in 2018, which obviously means this depth chart is a bit crowded. Warring is a massive specimen at 6-foot-5, 252 pounds. The San Diego State product is a capable blocker and his combination of size, speed (4.67 40-yard dash), quickness, route-running ability and athleticism offers him big-time upside as a receiver. The small-handed former basketball star has struggled with drops (seven on 85 FBS targets) and post-catch production (prospect-worse 2.8 RAC last season), but makes sense as a developmental flier. He's likely to be buried on the depth chart in 2019.

name: Eagles D/ST
weekly_outlook: The Eagles' D/ST finished as a top-six fantasy unit in Doug Pederson's first two seasons with the team but plummeted to 26th last season. The Eagles struggled in nearly every area, falling from fourth in forced turnovers, yardage allowed and points allowed in 2017 to 22nd, 23rd and 12th, respectively, last season. They didn't score a D/ST touchdown after managing at least five in each of the previous four seasons. The Eagles lost Jordan Hicks, Michael Bennett and Haloti Ngata but added Malik Jackson, Vinny Curry, Andrew Sendejo and Zach Brown in the offseason. The newcomers join a group led by Fletcher Cox, Malcolm Jenkins and Brandon Graham. This is a good defense and prime rebound candidate. A Week 1 home matchup with Washington adds to the unit's draft appeal.

name: Packers D/ST
weekly_outlook: Green Bay's D/ST ranked 23rd in fantasy points last season, which marked the unit's third consecutive finish outside the top 20. The Packers struggled badly in most departments, ranking 29th in interceptions (seven) and forced turnovers (15), 26th in tackles for loss (80), 15th in yardage allowed (5,670) and 11th in points allowed (400). On the plus side, the unit ranked eighth with 44 sacks, which marks the Packers' seventh top-10 finish in the category the past nine seasons. Muhammad Wilkerson and Nick Perry (both barely played last season), as well as Clay Matthews, are gone, but Adrian Amos, Preston Smith, Za'Darius Smith, Rashan Gary and Darnell Savage were key offseason additions. They join Kenny Clark, Mike Daniels, Blake Martinez and Jaire Alexander to form an intriguing sleeper D/ST.

name: Sam Darnold
weekly_outlook: Darnold was a 21-year-old Week 1 starter for a Jets offense lacking a good supporting cast last season. It showed. The 2018 third-overall pick struggled to a 58 percent completion percentage (third worst) and 6.9 yards per attempt (10th worst), though part of that can be attributed to a 9.4 aDOT (fourth highest). Working behind a weak offensive line, Darnold was pressured on 25 percent of his dropbacks (sixth most), took 30 sacks and missed three games with an injury. On the plus side, Darnold finished strong once healthy, posting six TDs and just one INT with a 7.4 YPA during his final four games. The youngster will have more help and a new coaching staff in 2019, so it's fair to expect another step forward. He's a back-end QB2 and breakout candidate.

name: Christian McCaffrey
weekly_outlook: If not for being rested during a meaningless Week 17 game, McCaffrey would've led all backs in fantasy points last season. The Stanford product took his game to a new level in 2018, playing an almost unheard of 97 percent of Carolina's snaps through Week 16. He finished 10th among backs in rushing attempts (219) and was first in targets (124), receptions (107) and receiving yards (867). McCaffrey had at least five receiving touchdowns for the second year in a row. He improved his yards per carry from 3.7 to 5.0 and his catch rate from 73 percent to 86 percent. The 23-year-old does it all and is well worth the early-first-round fantasy investment.

name: Nick Chubb
weekly_outlook: Chubb opened his NFL career buried behind both Carlos Hyde and Duke Johnson, but it didn't take long for the 2018 second-round pick to force his way into a massive role. Once he took over as the lead back in Week 7, Chubb handled 80 percent of the Browns' designed runs and 10 percent of the targets, and only seven backs scored more fantasy points. For the entire season, Chubb averaged 5.2 YPC (10th-highest at the position), including 2.41 after contact (seventh-best), and he averaged 0.53 fantasy points per snap, which was fourth-highest among backs. Chubb will open 2019 as Cleveland's clear feature back, though a limited role as a receiver and the return of Kareem Hunt around midseason limit his upside a bit. Chubb is best viewed as a strong RB2 in Cleveland's improved offense.

name: Odell Beckham Jr.
weekly_outlook: Following a tumultuous but highly productive five seasons in New York, Beckham was traded to the Browns during the offseason. After finishing each of his first three NFL seasons with 1,300-plus receiving yards, 10-plus touchdowns and as a top-7 fantasy receiver, Beckham has managed a total of 1,354 yards and nine touchdown receptions while missing 16 of 32 games because of injury during the past two seasons. Though his play came back to earth a bit in 2018, Beckham ranked top 8 at the position in fantasy points per game for the fourth time in five seasons. Baker Mayfield's new No. 1 target is a strong bet to blow by 1,000 receiving yards for the fifth time in six seasons. The 26-year-old is a midpack WR1 with elite upside.

name: James Conner
weekly_outlook: Second-year Conner was abruptly thrown into the fire last season with Le'Veon Bell sitting out the season. Conner picked up where his predecessor left off, handling 81 percent of the team's carries and 13 percent of the targets prior to suffering an injury in Week 13. During those 13 weeks, Conner put up 1,368 scrimmage yards and 13 touchdowns, which helped him to the fifth-most fantasy points among running backs. Conner's efficiency was solid and, unlike Bell, he benefited from getting many carries inside the opponent's 5-yard line (15, third-most). With Bell now in New York, the 24-year-old Conner returns as the Steelers' clear feature back. He's a back-end RB1.

name: JuJu Smith-Schuster
weekly_outlook: Smith-Schuster is the new main man in Pittsburgh after the Steelers shipped Antonio Brown to Oakland. Smith-Schuster should be able to handle it considering he's fresh off arguably the best second season for a second-year wide receiver in league history. Smith-Schuster paced all wide receivers in pass routes (662) and finished no lower than seventh in targets (167), receptions (111) and receiving yards (1,383). Smith-Schuster has scored seven touchdowns during each of his two NFL seasons, though his 8.3 OTD and 13 end zone targets in 2018 suggest he was a bit unlucky in that department. Smith-Schuster's targets might not rise significantly in 2019, but that's only because he was already a huge part of the offense. Incredibly still only 22, Smith-Schuster's best days still could be ahead of him. He's a solid WR1 with upside to lead the position in fantasy points.

name: Mike Evans
weekly_outlook: Evans has finished no lower than 11th in targets, no lower than 12th in receiving yardage and no lower than eighth in OTD among wide receivers during each of the past four seasons. Despite that consistency, his fantasy output has been inconsistent due to fluctuating touchdown output. After catching 12 touchdowns as a rookie, his totals have been 3, 12, 5 and 8, respectively. Evans was fantasy's No. 9 wideout last season despite a career-low 23 percent target share. Impressively, he caught a career-high 62 percent of his targets despite a career-high 15.7 aDOT. Evans ranked third among receivers in both YPR (17.7) and YPT (11.0) and sits second in the NFL with 88 end zone targets since entering the league. The 6-foot-5 25-year-old is a fringe WR1.

name: Chris Godwin
weekly_outlook: Godwin was limited to 57 percent of the Buccaneers' pass plays last season but still managed a 59/842/7 line and 27th-place finish in fantasy points. The 2017 third-round pick ranked 52nd at the position in routes, but was 25th in receiving yards and 13th in touchdowns thanks to a solid 9.0 YPT and 14 end zone targets (sixth most). Godwin has three drops on 150 career targets and has ranked top 5 in first down rate each of his two NFL seasons. New coach Bruce Arians, whose wide receivers ranked fifth in fantasy points during his five seasons as Arizona's head coach, says he believes Godwin could push for 100 catches in 2019. That might be a stretch, but Godwin is well positioned for a run at a top 20 fantasy season.

name: DJ Moore
weekly_outlook: Moore was the first wide receiver selected in the 2018 draft and it didn't take long for the Maryland product to take on a large offensive role. Moore first played more than half of Carolina's offensive snaps in Week 8 and was fantasy's No. 20 wideout from that point forward. He ended up 31st at the position in receiving yards (788) despite ranking 53rd in pass routes (406) thanks to a league-best average of 7.7 yards after catch. He was limited to two touchdowns (2.2 OTD), but offset that a bit with 172 rushing yards. The versatile 22-year-old is now Carolina's clear No. 1 wide receiver and well positioned for a second-year breakout. He's a fringe WR2.

name: Jarvis Landry
weekly_outlook: Landry has finished as a top 20 fantasy receiver each of the past four seasons, but he hit his lowest mark during that span last season (18th) and that was before Cleveland's trade for Odell Beckham Jr. Landry has handled a target share of at least 27 percent during each of the past four seasons, but he's unlikely to come close to that mark in 2019. The 2014 second-round pick enjoyed a 32 percent share during Weeks 1-8 last season, but plummeted to 21 percent once Freddie Kitchens took over the offense; he was 28th at the position in fantasy points during Kitchens' eight games. Landry's catch rate plummeted to 55 percent in 2018 after clearing 67 percent in all four seasons in Miami. There's enough volume to allow Landry WR3 production, but he's now second fiddle to Beckham.

name: Greg Olsen
weekly_outlook: Injuries have derailed Olsen's past two seasons, limiting the veteran tight end to 44 catches for 482 yards and five touchdowns in 16 games during that span. Olsen played a majority of the snaps in seven games last season and was fantasy's No. 8 scoring tight end. Olsen's slump came after he ranked no lower than second at the position in snaps in five consecutive seasons, finishing each as a top-seven fantasy tight end. Olsen is expected back for Week 1 and should be no lower than third on the team in targets behind Christian McCaffrey and DJ Moore. Olsen is no spring chicken at 34 years old, but he's an obvious rebound candidate and can be had at a major discount late in drafts. He's worth a flier.

name: Curtis Samuel
weekly_outlook: Samuel has missed 10 games and registered a grand total of 54 receptions since being selected in the second round of the 2017 draft. The versatile receiver has struggled with efficiency, having hauled in 59 percent of his targets while posting a 6.6 YPT and 3.0 RAC. Samuel did make some noise in the touchdown department last season, scoring seven times on 47 touches, though his 4.4 OTD suggests he was over his head. Samuel played at least 60 percent of Carolina's snaps in five games last season and was fantasy's No. 32 WR those weeks. There's third-year breakout potential here, so Samuel is fine mid-to-late-round option.

name: Baker Mayfield
weekly_outlook: Mayfield enjoyed one of the best rookie quarterback campaigns of all time last season and Cleveland's offseason addition of Odell Beckham Jr. only adds to his 2019 fantasy appeal. Head coach Freddie Kitchens took over as Cleveland's playcaller in Week 9 last season and Mayfield scored the 10th-most fantasy points among QBs from that point forward. During those eight games, Cleveland averaged 3.1 touchdowns per game (fifth most), 76 percent of which were passes (fifth highest). Mayfield adds little with his legs and needs to cut down on interceptions, which could limit his fantasy upside a bit, but entering his second season with Beckham, Jarvis Landry, David Njoku and Nick Chubb at his disposal, Mayfield can safely be considered a fringe QB1 with big upside. Side note: The Buccaneers led the NFL in both passing yards and interceptions during new Browns offensive coordinator Todd Monken's three seasons with the team.

name: O.J. Howard
weekly_outlook: Howard finished 2018 as the No. 14 scoring tight end, which is impressive when you consider he missed six games due to injury. Howard, who ranked sixth prior to the injury, accomplished the feat with low volume (4.7 targets per game) and elite efficiency (Howard has led the position in both YPT and YPR in both of his two NFL seasons). Howard has also scored touchdowns at an unsustainable rate (11 career TDs, 5.9 career OTD). The 24-year-old is clearly a rising star, but durability (eight missed games) and the presence of new coach Bruce Arians (his tight ends ranked 31st in fantasy points during five seasons in Arizona) are red flags. But Howard has played too well to be discounted. He has elite upside but will cost you a sixth round pick.

name: Peyton Barber
weekly_outlook: An undrafted free-agent signing back in 2016, Barber plodded his way to a pair of nondescript first two NFL seasons. He was forced into a much larger role in 2018, however, with second-round pick Ronald Jones struggling badly immediately upon joining the team. Barber went on to rack up 234 carries (ninth-most), but failed to impress, averaging a career-low 3.7 YPC (1.9 YAC). Despite ranking 10th at the position in snaps (583), Barber was targeted only 28 times. He turned those looks into 20 catches for 92 yards (3.3 YPT). Barber finished five weeks better than 37th at the position in fantasy points. The Buccaneers will be hoping for a much better season from Jones, but even if Barber remains the starter, he's a replacement-level back who is only worth a mid-to-late pick.

name: Kareem Hunt
weekly_outlook: Following a top-five fantasy campaign as a rookie, Hunt was well on his way to a repeat performance in 2018, having scored 14 touchdowns in 11 games. However, when video surfaced of an off-field assault, Hunt was released by Kansas City and sat out the rest of the season. Hunt signed with Cleveland, though he will be suspended for the first eight games of 2019. Hunt is entering his age-24 season and has been one of the league's most effective backs over the past two seasons. He's averaging 4.8 YPC (2.5 YAC) on 453 attempts and an outstanding 8.4 YPT on 99 targets. Hunt will be an intriguing handcuff down the stretch, and he's talented enough to push Nick Chubb for touches, but it's hard to imagine a significant impact as long as Chubb is healthy. Hunt is worth stashing on season-long rosters only in leagues with deep benches.

name: Jameis Winston
weekly_outlook: Winston's 2018 season was marred by a three-game suspension and an interception-fueled benching, but he still ended up showing improvement in several areas. Winston completed 65 percent of his passes and was off target on 16 percent of his attempts, both of which were career-best marks. Winston also rushed for a career-high 281 yards despite appearing in just 11 games. During the nine weeks he started, Winston ranked fourth in fantasy points. He continues to struggle with interceptions (58 in 56 career games), though part of that is a product of a propensity for attacking deep down field (he's ranked top five in aDOT in all four seasons). Winston has flashed enough to keep him in the QB1 discussion.

name: Vance McDonald
weekly_outlook: A consistent 2018 campaign led McDonald to a career-best 10th-place finish in fantasy points. The veteran tight end handled at least four targets in 12 of 15 games and scored between six and 14 fantasy points in 13 games. He ended up with a 50-640-4 line, and his eight end-zone targets were fifth most at the position. McDonald's 7.8 RAC was fourth-best last season, and he's never finished a season in which he's handled 40-plus targets lower than ninth in the category. A position-high 17 percent of his targets were on screens last season. With Antonio Brown and Jesse James gone, McDonald could move as high as second in targets on a good Steelers offense. The 29-year-old is a fine TE1.

name: Ronald Jones II
weekly_outlook: Jones was one of the youngest players selected in the 2018 draft, and maybe that's the excuse for what was an ugly rookie season. The second-round pick struggled right out of the gate and ended up managing only 88 snaps in nine games. He registered 44 yards on 23 carries (1.9 YPC, 1.3 YAC) and 33 yards on nine targets (3.7 YPT). Jones is undersized at 5-foot-11, 205 pounds, which might limit his early-down and goal-line opportunities, but the depth chart is wide open in Tampa Bay. He's a post-hype sleeper with tons of raw talent and upside as a receiver. Throw a dart in the late rounds.

name: Cam Newton
weekly_outlook: Newton was well on his way to one of his best seasons in 2018, but a shoulder injury derailed him down the stretch. Newton sat third at the position in fantasy points through Week 13, but was limited to a pair of weeks outside the top 20 prior to being shut down for Weeks 16 and 17. We saw a new-look Newton, as his 7.3 aDOT was easily a career low and led to career-best marks in completion rate (68 percent) and off-target rate (14 percent). The result? Carolina scored two-plus offensive touchdowns in every game through Week 14. Even missing two games, Newton finished top five at the position in carries, rushing yards and rushing touchdowns for the eighth consecutive season. If he's healthy for Week 1, Newton remains a solid QB1 play with upside.

name: Steelers D/ST
weekly_outlook: Believe it or not, the Steelers have led the NFL in sacks the past two seasons. They generated 52 last season to go with 99 tackles for loss (eighth-most) while allowing 5.3 yards per play (sixth-best) and blocking three kicks (second-most). Pittsburgh's D/ST salvaged an eighth-place fantasy season despite ranking 29th in forced turnovers (15), its lowest total since 2011 (15). Following minimal offseason turnover, Pittsburgh remains outstanding up front with T.J. Watt, Cameron Heyward, Stephon Tuitt and Javon Hargrave leading the way. The unit is suspect beyond that, though LB Devin Bush was scooped up in the first round of the draft, and Steven Nelson is an underrated addition at corner. This is a mid-pack D/ST option in 2019, though a Week 1 trip to New England hurts the draft appeal.

name: David Njoku
weekly_outlook: Njoku entered the NFL extremely young, at 20 years old, and is now entering the all-important third NFL season. The 2017 first-round pick's snaps and targets increased substantially last season, which helped him to a ninth-place finish in fantasy points (he was 10th during Freddie Kitchen's eight games as offensive coordinator). A dangerous threat down the seam, Njoku has ranked top 11 at the position in aDOT in each of his two pro seasons. Last season's 16 percent target share figures to decrease slightly with Beckham in the fold, but it's possible Njoku overcomes that with an extra touchdown or two (he has exactly four in each of his two seasons). The 23-year-old is a fringe TE1 with upside.

name: James Washington
weekly_outlook: The Steelers have a lengthy resume of developing wide receivers into stars, and Washington could be next. The 2018 second-round pick underwhelmed as a rookie, but he was an explosive downfield playmaker at Oklahoma State and last preseason. With Antonio Brown gone, Washington will compete with Donte Moncrief and rookie Diontae Johnson for No. 2 duties opposite JuJu Smith-Schuster in an offense that set a franchise record for touchdowns last season. Washington, whose vertical role yielded a 16.2 aDOT on 37 targets last season, has WR2 upside if he's able to carve out an every-down role in his second season. He's a high-risk/high-reward prospect worth your attention in the middle rounds.

name: Browns D/ST
weekly_outlook: Cleveland's D/ST finished 2018 25th in fantasy points, which was an improvement on the previous three seasons. Although 25th doesn't sound good, it doesn't tell the whole picture. Cleveland allowed 6,288 yards (third-most), surrendered 392 points (12th-most) and failed to score a non-offensive touchdown but intercepted 17 passes (fifth-most), forced 18 fumbles (sixth-most), posted 75 passes defensed (fifth-most) and had 101 tackles for loss (fifth-most). They ranked 28th in sack rate but added Olivier Vernon and Sheldon Richardson in the offseason. They join Myles Garrett, Denzel Ward, Joe Schobert and Greedy Williams to lead what is a solid but not flawless unit. Especially with a Week 1 home matchup against Tennessee on tap, Cleveland is an intriguing 2019 sleeper D/ST.

name: Donte Moncrief
weekly_outlook: The Steelers signed Moncrief this offseason not long after trading Antonio Brown to Oakland. Moncrief has had an up-and-down and -- at times -- injury-plagued career since being drafted in the third round of the 2014 draft. Moncrief's best season came in 2015 in which he posted a 64/733/6 line and was fantasy's No. 36 scoring wideout. He missed 11 games over the next two seasons with Indianapolis before posting a 48/668/3 line in 16 games with Jacksonville last season. Moncrief has underwhelmed thus far in his career, but he has been more productive with Andrew Luck under center and he'll certainly get good quarterback play via Ben Roethlisberger in Pittsburgh. Playing time is there for the taking with the depth chart wide open behind JuJu Smith-Schuster. The 26-year-old is a very intriguing post-hype sleeper.

name: Ben Roethlisberger
weekly_outlook: Despite all the drama surrounding Antonio Brown and Le'Veon Bell, the Steelers' offense managed to set a franchise record with 51 touchdowns last season. Roethlisberger, of course, is the primary reason for that. The now-37-year-old passer paced the NFL in dropbacks (712), attempts (675) and completions (452), while finishing top five in passing yards (5,086), passing touchdowns (34) and fantasy points (342) last season. Roethlisberger has finished eighth or better in fantasy points per game each of the past five seasons. Losing Brown can't be ignored, but Roethlisberger still has JuJu Smith-Schuster, James Conner and a strong offensive line at his disposal. He's a solid QB1 target.

name: Diontae Johnson
weekly_outlook: The Steelers drafted Johnson with the No. 66 pick of April's draft. The Toledo product will be counted on to help replace Antonio Brown, whom Pittsburgh traded to Oakland earlier in the offseason. Johnson is a small receiver (5-foot-10, 183 pounds) with good quickness, playmaking ability and post-catch skill (8.5 RAC in 2018). Johnson played both the slot (37 percent in 2018) and perimeter at Toledo, while contributing as a receiver (225 targets) and returner (79 kick, 17 punt) during his three seasons. His hands need work (seven drops last season) and he disappointed at the combine, especially in the 40-yard dash (4.53). Pittsburgh is terrific at developing wide receivers, so this is a good long-term landing spot for Johnson, but he figures to work as a situational receiver and returner in 2019.

name: Jaylen Samuels
weekly_outlook: After working with the tight ends during the 2018 combine, Samuels was drafted by Pittsburgh in the fifth round and "converted" to tailback. Samuels played 54 snaps off the bench during Weeks 1-13, but James Conner's injury forced him into lead back duties during the team's final four games. Samuels impressed, rushing for 225 yards on 44 carries (5.1 YPC) and catching 19 of 21 targets for 145 yards. Despite scoring one touchdown, Samuels ranked 12th among backs in fantasy points during that span. Samuels is a terrific pass-catcher (his 87 percent catch rate was second-best at the position), who is expected to open 2018 as a change-of-pace and receiving back behind Conner. Samuels and rookie Benny Snell Jr. would handle backfield duties in the event of a Conner injury.

name: Ricky Seals-Jones
weekly_outlook: A converted wide receiver, Seals-Jones generated some hype last season when called on to play an every-down role for Arizona. It didn't go well for the 2017 undrafted free agent. Despite handling a generous 15 percent target share, Seals-Jones finished 29th in fantasy points, and his best weekly finish was 10th. His 50 percent catch rate and 5.0 YPT both ranked dead last at the position, though in his defense, a position-high 25 percent of balls thrown his way were off-target. The 24-year-old was waived by Arizona and is now depth in Cleveland. He is not worth drafting.

name: Cameron Brate
weekly_outlook: Brate has finished top 15 among tight ends in pass routes each of the past three seasons but has seen his fantasy production progressively dip during that span. Brate posted a 57-660-8 line and was fantasy's No. 7 tight end in 2016. He fell to 10th in 2017 and 19th in 2018 despite appearing in all 32 of the team's games over that stretch. Brate's calling card has been touchdowns, as he's the only tight end who has scored at least six touchdowns each of the past three seasons. Brate was fantasy's No. 16 tight end during the six weeks O.J. Howard was out last season, which even puts a damper on his handcuff appeal. He has minimal fantasy value.

name: Jarius Wright
weekly_outlook: Carolina operated its pass-heaviest offense during the Cam Newton era last season, which led to a third wide receiver seeing the field on 85% of its pass plays. That was third highest in the NFL. Wright quietly caught 43 passes for 447 yards last season while focusing his time on the short area (6.0 aDOT was second-lowest at the position and his 74% catch rate was sixth best). His role, as well as the presence of Christian McCaffrey, DJ Moore, Curtis Samuel and Greg Olsen, severely limits his fantasy appeal, though it's fair to say he's among the deepest of sleepers in oversized PPR leagues.
